Posted: November 29, 2015
												Unlike Call of Duty - Black Ops II, this actually gets Afghanistan right. The setting looks like the mountains I flew over and the valley I rucked in. It looks like Afghanistan, it sounds like Afghanistan, and despite the game-isms, does a good job of telling the story.  Little things stand out to me - the visible selector switch from semi to full, the relatively realistic weapons models, the radio chatter and dialogue - as authentic. There are some reality breakers, like a general in a suit during cutscenes or the wrong time period highspeed gofast gear on dudes in a game set in 2001, but I can put them aside and enjoy the atmosphere.The campaign isn't going to appeal to everyone. It's shorter than some, and it's not full of Michael Bay explosions like the Call of Duty series (which I also own). What makes the single player shine is that it's based on real events. The set pieces (vehicle sections, stand-and-fights) are well presented, and logically flow with the game. There's a sense of being part of a larger picture with the radio chatter between AFOs Neptune and Wolfpack and their boss ('Jimmy,' or COL Drucker in the cutscenes). Your actions make sense, and several times throughout the game you'll see the other AFO doing their part of the missions.It's worth picking up, on sale or full price, and getting a solid play through. If you want to see a more realistic shooter than the Call of Duty series with a story grounded in actual events, this is the one. This is probably the most under-appreciated military shooter in recent memory for me, purely as an on-the-rails gut wrench adrenaline ride (the downhill scramble to the chopper and the stand-your-ground sequences in particular). Yeah, there's hand-holding, but it the game it makes sense. No one plays rambo in real life, because that's how you die.

												As a veteran, I've played through the campaign three times now with a year in between each. It's not a Hollywood blockbuster movie, so don't have an expectation of that.  It's gritty and dirty, and leaves you with mixed emotions that are hard to recognize at the end.  You may feel sad, angry,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off, sad again...and ultimately thankful.  All rolled into one.The story is good, and for me, emotional.  It brings back the memories of camaraderie, of knowing deep down that for your buddies, you'll run through a fusillade of fire in order to drag them out if need be.  For me, it's powerfully moving, and at the end, I just sit and let time take me backwards until it's time to return to the present again.Functionally, the visuals are somewhat dated, but they work.  The gunplay is as expected for a game and breaks from reality sometimes (no one reloads with the exact same speed, accuracy and deft paws that are chronicled here everytime you do so, it just doesn't happen due to Murphy's Law). The sounds are good, and the voice acting is very convincing.  Most of the major players sound just like you would expect elite operators to sound like.If you like first-person shooters and a good, albeit short, storyline, pick it up.  Especially if it's on sale for $5 or so.  Worth it.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
Note: the following review covers only the single player campaign.There was a point in time when Medal of Honor was a series that mattered. A franchise born in a time where WWII shooters were still hot and Allied Assault was blowing players and its competition away. But between then and now bolt action rifles and beach stormings have fallen out of fashion, most of the people who made Medal of Honor a respected name among shooters have long since left for other studios, and 2010’s reboot (for lack of a more appropriate term) is left doing the same thing so many other games were a decade or so ago when the series was first kicking off: attempting to ape its peers in the hope of grabbing a slice of the pie.Today’s analogical pastry is the impossibly large Call of Duty, which along with its innovations in campaign structures and online play brought itself out of the early 20th century and into modern day. Naturally every other military shooter has followed suit, but Medal of Honor is perhaps the first to really attempt to ground itself in the ongoing conflicts happening in the middle east, a decision that could have given its campaign meaning outside of itself and showcased to its players the very real horrors raging on in Afghanistan which somehow still feel so distant.Instead we end up with exactly what you’d expect from a modern military shooter, except coming along with the added baggage of playing off actual current events, which for all of developer Danger Close’s intentions has only managed to turn the game into a giant mess. It’s not that I expected Medal of Honor to provide any meaningful commentary on the scenarios its portraying, but by marrying its summer action movie mentality to a war that’s still raging and killing thousands it trivializes the losses of American soldiers and innocent Afghans for mindless entertainment.Medal of Honor is happy to proclaim itself as being “real” only so far as it can manage to fit in a blockbuster sequence of set pieces and explosions, showing you how horrible the things its replicating are one second while reveling in gory headshots and idiotic “bro-speak” the next. It feels emotionally manipulative and tasteless, unwilling to commit to being anything but a dumb action game with as little nuance in presenting its subject matter as that usually entails.And what an unbelievably dumb game Medal of Honor is. Below its terribly handled premise, incoherent plot, and attempts at “gritty realism”, there’s a game that’s terrified of letting you play it. It funnels you through levels with gratuitous levels of restriction, placing invisible walls everywhere so as to always be entirely in control of where you are and where you can go even if it intends to let you there later. You move when it tells you to, shoot where it points you, watch the often malfunctioning scripted sequences sometimes when it makes you, and participate in its series of strict directions because that’s all you can do.Medal of Honor is so obsessed with being in control that I began to ask why I was even there at all. The game clearly didn’t want me there, as I became one more thing needing to be kept on a leash, in case I potentially walk too far ahead and break another scripting trigger or stumble into an area before it’s had time to spawn its enemies, and I didn’t want to be there because the lack of any player agency made it feel like I was watching a very dull movie that I had to keep moving forward.But it’s probably the incompetency with which the game hides any of this that’s the most insulting. There’s never any question that you’re being moved through egregiously linear environments, shooting enemies with zero tactical awareness that pop up like target dummies with guns that never feel right. The game presents itself entirely as it is, as if it hasn’t even enough pride to try and hide its mind numbing tediousness and genericism; to try and pretend it wasn’t plopped out in the hopes of catching hold of Call of Duty’s momentum because it hasn’t a single original idea left for itself. In a way I kind of appreciate this sort of honesty, if only because it’s the only bit of sincerity the game ever shows.You can find more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

Posted: June 13, 2016
												First of all, Medal of Honor's single-player and multi-player modes are literally two different games with different graphics and gameplay.The single-player part is kind of generic, but still may be fun. Every level offers something different: breaking through enemies' lines with your squadmates, perfroming a stealthy mission, playing as a helicopter gunner, operating an anti-materiel rifle, etc. Voice acting is very good. Guns feel realistic and are nice to use. The graphics are dated, but still good for a 2010 game. In my book, the biggest flaws in Medal of Honor are its modest length (about 5h) and its difficulty, or rather its absence: even on the hardest difficulty level enemies lack aggression and are not so dangerous; your character can survive more hits than you'd expect. Beating a level without dying once is not a hard task, especially if you're an experienced gamer. Overall, the single-player mode is decent, but feels more like an interactive war movie. I haven't played the multiplayer mode a lot, however I can confirm people are still playing it and there are active servers. Gameplay-wise it's similar to Battlefield: Bad Company 2 or Battlefield 3 (as it was made by DICE, creators of Battlefield), but with smaller maps, faster gameplay, no vehicles and a few CoD-like killstreaks.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2013
												!Single Player Only Review!It was supposed to be the game that would break Activision's CoD empire, it was supposed to be the game that would reestablish the once great Meda of Honor name. Now, it's a game that will no-one remember and the game that fell short in every aspect it could have.The story of MoH itself is uninteresting, undercooked and short. The game can be finished in a mere 5 hours on normal settings, without any, and I mean ANY replay value. There aren't any collectibles, multiple paths or story elements that would encourage the player to start the game all over again. Once you have finished it semi-frustrated there is no going back to it. Frustration is a concept that will many of us have to face in MoH. The super-linear nature of the discourages any way of alternate pathfinding. To put it simple, if you don't do what the game says you to do, you're dead. Don't try to be a hero, as you always have to follow instructions to survive. If you are told to hold position, don't try to peek above the wall, because you are getting shot. If you are told to run or retreat don't try to stay and hold off the enemy as they will kill you...sometimes even behind cover.Not is all bad about the game however. Two things stand out the most. The graphics are beautiful even on medium settings. Water, rocks, buildings and shadows look astonishing. The other thing where you have to give credit to the creators is trying to maintain authenticity. Places, soldiers, the way they talk to each other, situations all feel real to a person who is inexperienced in war situations. The game itself takes place in Afghanistan and it's plot is loosely based on the Operation Anaconda where US soldiers tried to destroy Taliban forces back in '02.I can honestly say that I haven't seen a game that would want YOU to rush through it's single player mode. This game does. For one thing its ultra short. Experienced player can finish it in 4 to 5 hours easily, and checkpoints are so frequent that even if you happen to die, you won't be set back for more than 2 minutes of your progress. Literally, a level starts with an in-game cinematic and a shepherd is taken down silently by your fellow soldier, and boom checkpoint. Sometimes it feels like the game throws you a CP every time you reload you weapon. The level design is also horrible, excluding the first few stages, on all of the levels there is 1 hard point where you are so overwhelmed that you will die 3-10 times in 5 minutes. Up until that point and even after that there is little to no resistance. To put it gently, it's unbalanced.When you get frustrated (and you'll get) by the SP you can try the Tier1 mode, which is unlocked once you've completed the SP on any difficulty. Basically, Tier1 is the same as the SP just with some gameplay tweaks, e.g. difficulty is set to hard and you have no restarts. Once you die, you have to start over again. There is a time limit in each level that you have to beat, and headshots will freeze the timer for a couple of seconds. To conserve time there aren't any cutscenes either. This mode really is for hardcore MoH players and I doubt that any of the one-timers will enjoy it.Rating: 47/100; Replay Value: 1/5; To Beat: 5 hours; Played on: normal.

												Medal of Honor is a First-Person shooter, and also the thirteenth game in the series, taking place in Afghanistan, instead of the previous titles which took place during The Second World War. Released in 2010, Medal of Honor, has you conducting hostage rescues, and raiding hideouts, while navigating through dangerous territories filled with insurgents. IED's and realistic ambushes put you in the crosshairs and make you feel like you are actually in the firefights. The realism we've come to expect from the Medal of Honor series does not disappoint. You play the game as one of several different characters throughout the missions, from Navy Seals to Army Rangers. The story takes place beginning in 2001 during the beginning of the Afghanistan invasion. The game also has multiplayer mode, which features three different classes; Rifleman, Special Operations, and Snipers. An interesting title, one I would recommend to anyone who doesn't have PTSD, as the realistic quality and content could be psychologically damaging.

Posted: July 27, 2015
												If you manage to get this game for very low price, it's worth trying out.Well-optimised, not too hardware-demanding, runs on max settings without any hiccups, with good graphics.The singleplayer is good:I like the Afghanistan and military atmosphere. Audio is very good, graphics are beautiful and sharp. Character animations are somewhat good.The story is short, characters are noticable but rather character-less (bearded guy with a cap).There's no customisation, no ranks and no collectibles, in singleplayer. The cover system is working great.But as said, it's good - I installed this game because I felt like playing a shooter, taking place in Afghanistan (or something with lot of sand) and I got just what I needed.The singleplayer deserves a 7/10 rank, not bad. Good atmosphere and fun combat.The multiplayer is extremly mediocre. Very few players still play, but you find one-two full servers every now-and-then.While singleplayer is running on beautiful and polished Unreal Engine, the multiplayer is powered by a watered-down Frostbite engine. They removed cover mechanics, character animations suck, detection of hits is pretty damn bad, maps are too small and most of killing is ruthless spawntrapping. Movement is extremly sloppy and bulky, there are problems with delay (even if your ping is low).At least, I didn't encounter any blatant cheating, at least something.The unlock system is decent. Also weapon customisation. There are three classes, each one has unique equipment for both faction (Taliban and US).Rarely, you get a good match with the right type of players, in that case the multiplayer is great. But as said - very rarely.Multiplayer deserves the ranking of around 5/10, not sure. It mainly suffers from the engine, removal of features (comparing to singleplayer) and strange map and encounter design.

Because some stupid videoreview I saw on it on gamestar.de, that told only how bad the game is - and only talked about the negative points of this game. You will almost never be on your own but always togehter with your squad, and they talk a lot but none of it is crap or hollywood♥♥♥♥♥♥like in Medal of Honor. It just sounds perfect like military radio communication. The sounds are awesome. For example one of your squad members talks, you see his lips move, you hear him over the radio in your ear, but you also hear him talking normally because he´s standing right next to you...   or there´s a sequence when you drop into a Valley, and each shot you do just sounds amazing like if you´d be in a real valley (no idea how to say this in english :-)... Of course the grafics are not top notch, of course there are some small bugs that we´re not even worth to mention, but the game itself is a great and very (or at least it seems so) authentic military experience... Awesome and I can fully recommend it. Just make sure u listen to what your squad members talk over the radio - because there´s a lot of information about what´s going on in it, and I think the reporter from gamestar.de just didn´t listen because he says the story is not existing and strange :-D....Only thing I kinda disliked- the sequence where you go by quad bike through the mountains, the feeling for the driving is just very badly done and I don´t feel it realistic neither because it´s a mission about stealth everywhere you stop - and then you just roam on on those loud bikes?... makes no sense to me. But as I said - ...overall, awesome game. Loved it.PS: Didn´t even try the Multyplayer as it´s 6 years old already today. But from the videoreviews I saw it seemed pretty good.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												WARNING: The FOV is set to 55, and no official FOV slider is present. There is an unofficial mod, but it's still in beta. Here is the link[community.pcgamingwiki.com]Medal of Honor 2010 is not a bad game, but it's not really a game that i would recommend.The game consists of a singleplayer campaign that was made by Danger Close and multiplayer that was made by DICE.SingleplayerCampaign is about the war in Afghanistan. Unlike most shooters now a days, they decided to focus solely on one place. You don't have this "travel round the world" that most shooters do these days, everything happens in one location.I also liked how they hand over missions to you. You start out as marines. During that level you get surrounded and call for air support.  Two helicopters come to the rescue and drive the enemy away, then you start playing as one of the pilots. By the end of their level, you almost get shot by an RPG, but a friendly sniper team prevents that from happening. Now you switch to that sniper team.During the sniper level, you provide assistance to a friendly unit. Then you switch to that unit.Unfortunately, the bad outweighs the good here. This game has your typical linear designed levels. Altogether the game isn't very long - only 4 hours. Also, a lot of features that were part of MOH Airborne are not present - like choosing your loadout, big open levels, choosing you starting point, upgrading your weapons.MultiplayerIt was made by DICE. It kind of resembles a mix between COD and Battlefield.Unlike the singleplayer, it uses Frostbite 1.5 (while the singleplayer uses Unreal Engine 3). Despite all that, the destruction is very insignificant though.It features 12 maps and 6 modes. Allows a max of 24 players. Also, it has a server browser. 5 maps are used for Team Assault (TDM), Sector Control (smaller Conquest) and Objective Raid (Rush without vehicles). 3 maps are used for Combat Mission (Rush with vehicles). 2 Maps for Hot Zone (King of the Hill).2 Maps for Clean Sweep (Counter Strike).Combat Mission is probably the main mode of the game. It's pretty much Rush, except that you have 5 objectives, and you defend one at a time. Unlike BF's Rush it doesn't have 2 objectives at any one time. For more traditional Rush, play Objective Raid. Unfortunately in that one, the game ends after one of the objectives blows up - no extra objectives.Defenders win if the time limit runs out. Attackers win if they destroy every objective.Taliban are always the defenders and US are always the attackers. US also gets an APC (unfortunately, it's only available on 2 maps).The game features 3 classes: Rifleman, Special Ops, Sniper. Rifleman gets access to assault rifles and machine guns. As well as smoke grenades and grenade launchers. Special Ops gets access to shotguns, carbines and SMGs. They also get rocket launchers. Sniper gets access to sniper rifles and C4.The leveling up is very similar to battlefield, that means, if you play as say Rifleman, you level up only the Rifleman class. Each class has 15 levels. Also, just like in Battlefield, you are stuck with respective weapons to your faction, and to use your enemy's weapons, you must reach the max level.There are a total of 15 weapons in the game, and you have 3 attachment slots for each of them.Now what it copied from COD are the killstreaks. They named them as pointstreaks. You can get them just by playing the objective or by getting kills. Once you die you lose your streak.Now, the other unique thing is that you are given a choice between a defensive or offensive killstreak.I feel that the multiplayer is just too low on content.ConclusionSingle player wise i think that this is a step backwards. Medal of Honor Airborne was a good example on how to make singleplayer games.Multiplayer is alright, but i doubt you will find anyone playing it these days. Considering the amount of content given, i wouldn't blame them.

												Reskinned Bad Company 2 with Call Of Duty sized maps that we all played on xbox years ago. Still a great game and I use it to benchmark older hardware. Great campaign. Side note: Back in 2010 this game faced a lot of controversy regarding the enemies in this game. People form the east were complaining about it being too real, in fact DICE almost changed enemy models to russian because of lawsuits. But eventually those went away as well. Side note 2: Medal of Honor Warfighter the follow up to this game follows a different story and also faced controversy. The game was produced by DICE but they had insider advice from former military agents about weapons ETC. The game was "TOO REAL" and was then degraded to civilian levels. From what I heard MOH WF had too many classified weapons and gadgets and the government didn't want these to be out in the wild yet "remember we were still dealing with Iraq in 2012" This game was being produced during the Bin Laden investigation and came out after his death. They made the same weapons about 5 times with no variation between them with different names to fill the void of the game they created. This ended up killing this game early and a unfinished product came out therefore ending the Medal of Honor franchise then. I suggest you go read up on it.

content:
Posted: April 9
												Very enthralling story set in the war in Afghanistan. Instead of taking the Call of Duty-approach of jumping between set-pieces all over the world you jump between a couple of different characters from a few special operations units carrying out small-scale attacks against (mainly) the Taliban. I loved this concept, it had me hooked from the get-go and got me through the entire campaign in one sitting. I played on the highest difficulty level and it lasted about 4,5 hours (well balanced difficulty, punishing you for getting hit instead of relying on bullet-sponge enemies in infinite waves). The story is a bit on the short side but at the same time completely without filler and loaded with well-written characters and thought out missions. It's more "Hollywood-realism" than power fantasy, meaning the missions feel credible while you never feel like Rambo. You still mow down hundreds of enemies á la the end of "Fury" but the prescense of AI-controlled squad mates make it feel like a team effort. Like previously mentioned, I really liked this take on story-telling and found it somewhat original for the genre.What I didn't like about the game was how limited the graphics options were. The game deactivates options it considers "out of your league", meaning I could not play this game at anything higher than 1440p "Medium" settings. As in there wasn't any options but "Low" and "Medium". Ridiculous. Fortunately the game still looks great and is very well optimized.I have not played the multiplayer and have no interest in doing so. The single-player however is one of the better ones I've played from the last decade. I loved it and would highly recommend this game  based on that experience.

I liked very much voice actors and music background.TL;DRIf you want to spend an evening, MoH is a nice way to do it, but get as cheaper you can on sale.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												This will be a review on the single player element of the game ONLY.TL;DRThe game is fun, solid shooting mechanics, it does a fantastic job of paying homage to those who have served in the Military. Also does a good job of recreating real life events. (To know what this game is based off of, search for the "Battle of Roberts Ridge")However the game has a frustrating lack of replayability, there's virtiually no choice in the game whatsoever, even so far as down to the pathing. Your compadres also treat you like how a cop would treat a kid on a ride-along.If you want a game that gives you freedom to explore, vast amounts of choice, and you can sacrifice the 'realism of war' and honor to veterans that this game provides, I would recommend you try out Crysis 1 instead.Okay. Longer review time here.I should probably preface this by saying that I played Medal of Honor Warfighter first, so I had very low expectations going in, however I'd looked up trailers for the single player and thought that it looked really really good. I'll also state my biases as someone who really wanted to join the service, but due to medical issues, can't, so games that honor soldiers are automatically a little higher on the scale than a similar game that just follows the normal trends.That being said. I'll start off with the pro's again.The shooting mechanics feel very solid in this game. That's honestly something that will make or break a game for me, I can't go back and play Black Ops 1 because it feels like the gun I'm holding is made of empty cardboard. But this game hit the nail on the head for me, the guns feel like they have weight to them, and it makes it very easy to control.Combine that with the serious nature of this game and how you want to pull everything off very precisely, it sort of wraps that whole combat experience up very nicely and the simple mechanics of it feel like a well oiled machine.Along with the shooting, you also have the option to melee your opponents, and this feels so satisfying to be able to do when you manage to sneak up on an opponent and melee them, especially because these moments are rare, for reasons they shouldn't be, but more on that in the negatives section.The tone of this game is also set up very very well, and I believe this is helped on by the story taking influence from actual events that occurred. I can't speak to all of the game, but there are specific levels (see the TL;DR) that drew influence from real life events. However, this level of historical accuracy does come with the cost of design and creative decisions you're allowed to make, its what separates this game from something like Crysis or Spec Ops The Line, more on that later though.Overal these positives boil down to a very solid single play through, you will have a lot of fun, but really only be able to do that once, so lets get down to why.So the negatives in this game.Lets start off with a half positive half negative. This game gives you individual characters to interact with, people with very different personality styles, so you're not just the singular hero surrounded by incompetent brainless AI, they actually are a team of people around you. But the game does this in a very shoddy way, I swear they all have the same face, with maybe different facial hair across a few of them, and an artist gave a few of them different Uniforms and different skin tones, and thats literally the only way to distinguish them outside of their voice. That and even though this is supposed to be a well oiled special operations unit, you still end up doing most of the leg-work for your team. Though that contrasts quite heavily against how it feels they treat you throughout the game.Little tangent here, but I swear you'll see how it ties in. So the designers of the game wanted you to follow a very specific path of how to complete the game yeah? Call of Duty has more variety in how you can approach scenarios, at least in that game they give you different corridors to shoot through, but rarely in this game will you find that. And tying in with that, the designers made it so that in several sections throughout the game, there are little ledges that you must drop down from, or climb over, but the only way to do that, is to wait for your teammates to give you a lift. How does this tie in now? Because your teammates bloody climb over that thing like its no big deal, you're just the chubby fat kid they ♥♥♥♥ing felt sorry for excluding and now they have to help you over the ledge cause you can't fit your love handles over it! But they can effortlessly do summer saults all over that bloody thing. Literally all they had to do to make you feel less like the incompetent team member that they still tell you to do everything in the game (Ramirez, take out that APC!) Is by tweaking the animations so that you help your teammates over that ledge too! Honestly, it doesn't just stop there, it honestly feels like you're the new guy on the team, and this team operates mostly autonomously of  any higher orders, sooo... probably something like Seal Team 6, since we're told somewhere that they're Navy Seals, plus all the ads for the game said Tier 1. But still, new guy on the team for Team 6 wouldn't be treated like the bumbling idiot it feels that you are! That along with how this whole, buddy hoist mechanic works, it really drains down the player choice. This game has none, and tats why there's little to no replayability for this game. There's one specific area where player choice would have been so easy to do, and would have been absolutely beautiful to see happen. (I'll have to spoil literally 10 minutes of the game to make my point) At one point in the game, you're tasked with taking out this mounted machine gunner who happens to have a position on a hill where he can shoot down on you. All the player is taske with doing, is using your SAW to provide supporting fire to your teammates, making this guy stop shooting. (I had trouble with this part some how and it literally took me an hour to get it to work) However there were several points in time where I was able to sneak around to the side of this guy, and get to a blind spot in his coverage where I could shoot this guy and he couldn't return fire. But whats bloody annoying is that this guy literalyl doesn't take bullet damage. The designers specifically took into account that I would try and do this, and safeguarded against it... Why not make it so that you can just shoot the dude right then and there? Instead of having the military waste a 125K$ rocket to blow up one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a mounted machine gun? Its just stuff like that which frustrates me with this game, there's zero choice within the game, and thus almost zero replayability.I think if the designers had taken a page from the book of the likes of Spec Ops The Line, or Specifically in this instance Crysis 1, where (for the latter example) You are allowed to move freely within your environment and tackle any situation how you want to, but it doesn't change the story whatsoever. Which is what I feel they were going for, a narrative based experience. Though personally, I would love to see a realistic shooter like this game, take some inferences from The Line, and have a branching storyline where you see someone go through feeling the effects of the chaos and brutality around them, but in a well oiled and finely tuned game like this. Because lets face it, while there's no way to deviate from the intended experience (its biggest fault) the intended experience is still a very solid one!Screw numbered ratings, this game is fun if you're down for a one time playthrough of a game, and especially so if you enjoy military shooters that have a good story along with them. If you absolutely can't play games that offer no choice in how you play them, don't buy this game, as stated before, there is rarely any opportunity to deviate from the intended experience.

Posted: October 26, 2016
												I honestly thought it was great. In the recent market of moddern warfare shooters, companies never get the balls to make a game about the actual modern wars. We've seen plenty of fake wars in the Battlefield and CoD series, straying from the real conflicts of WW2 that made those games successful. EA took the original concept of Medal of Honor, following valliant soldiers through the real life conflicts that have shaped our world, and brought it to the 21st century. Accompanied by music from Ramin Djawadi who's work I'm sure everyone is familiar with from Game of Thrones, this game truly takes a leap out of the standard Call of Fields that we've all become so used to. How EA managed to let a gem like this slip though the cracks without ruining it on the way out, I'll never know, but it truly is the unsung hero of modern day shooters. I'm not one to recommend FPS games like this, but I absolutely recommend this one if you care at all about the single player in FPS games. It's not just a Call of Duty clone.

												A triumph of game design! A  tour-de-force in everything that makes EA the creativity powerhouse it is today! An immaculate masterpiece that will surely be enjoyed for generations to come.I would bet that someone at EA wouldn't even believe that if they read it. They know what kind of company they are, and they know what kind of game they make. This game had no surpises, and I only played it to remove it from my "unplayed games" list. Ok, here's the review.EA's Least Shiatty Game since Medal of Honor: Allied Assault (actually, MOHAA was good. I'll give them that)"Let's relentlessly kill A-rabs for 2 hours!" Basically, it's pretty graphics and not much else. The gameplay is meh.... You're forced along a very strict path with glass walls if you try to stray even slightly.  There's one great scene where you approach a small village in an Apache (that you don't control, you just hold down m1+m2 and it shoots stuff), and they just say "Everyone is hostile here. Kill EVERYTHING" and you destroy every building in a village, undoubtedly killing children and civilians. There are lots of short easy gun battles between scripted events. The SEALs will tell you stuff like "be really really quiet here, we want to be sealthy". So you can, if you want, sneak along and kill nobody, or you can fire a few shots into the air, and your team will kill everyone for you. The controls are also screwed up too. For example, there was a mission where you're in a helicopter and all of a sudden you need hellfire missiles to take out a mortar, and the button for hellfire missiles isn't left click, right click, melee, grenade, or any of those keys, even though the last two of those are pointless in a helicopter. Instead, you have to hold down 4 for 2 seconds, even though there's nothing that binds 4 to any action. Really intuitive, right?1.5/5

												Medal of Honor is a fantastic addition to the string of modern warfare first-person shooters (FPS). The narrative, while brief, is a worthwhile experience that will leave you gaping for more. The graphics, gameplay and sounds will fully immerse you into the battlefields of Afghanistan given the game's detailed atmosphere. However, it should be noted that the singleplayer (SP) and multiplayer (MP) do not utilize the same game engine. While the SP uses a modified version of the Unreal Engine 3, the MP half uses DICE's Frostbite engine from the Battlefield series. Regardless, both the SP and the MP are worth a thorough playthrough. Keep in mind, that there are two DLC packs--"Hot Zone" and "Clean Sweep"--that are available exclusively at EA's store and will be unlocked via your in-game persona using redeemable codes.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												Medal of Honor throws you straight into the boots of a bad♥♥♥♥♥SEAL team, part of a 4-man group. As the story develops you not only get to play as only one single charachter, but many, in many different situations. This is undoubtedly the game's strong point - giving us as players, the chance to relate to, and understand and feel for other charachters as well, something that lacks greatly in other major AAA-titles. Albeit the game takes on a different approach, contrasting their previous WW2-installments, this one, given its new take on the series, has its own share of pros and cons. As it's been mentioned, charachter development is top-notch, not to mention the awesome graphics (although the game was released back in 2014) which still looks good up to this day. Drawbacks are unfortuneately the multiplayer part, with its numerous glitches, bugs, annoying controls and frankly, the lack of interesting content to give a real gameplay value, hence the bad score. Though, it's mentionworthy to say that they tried. And it's gotten even more polished in the sequel, Warfighter (not available on Steam). Another drawback is the feeling of doing the same mission, over and over, close to becoming annoying, but it never get's there (although pretty close). Last but not least, don't expect any long single-player campaign. It might be a short story, totalling around 4-5 hours. But you're into one hell of a ride, so it's by no means an "easy" challenge, to say the least.I'll give this game 3 solid SEALS out of 5!

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												SINGLE-PLAYER REVIEWFrom the serie that "started it all", that led the way for cinematic FPS games, I expected more than this. I played the whole MoH serie since the ps1 games, so I know how it was born and grew.The story is the usual, recycled, already seen soup, which is quite boring and you can skip with no regrets. The problem is that you can only skip movies and not cutsecenes, so if you want to replay the game, you'll have to watch them again and again, and they last for about 50% of the level time.The real problem is the gameplay, though. Being used to games that tells you everything you need to push in order to even move, so much that it gets annoying, I was surprised that this game tells you nothing at all. Well, it tells you what to push to move and jump, the basics that everyone already knows, but not how to use the special equipment you're supposed to use in the "mini-games". Ok, there's no mini-games here, but there's special sequences where you need to use a special binocular to mark targets for bombing, a sequence where you use the weaponry of an helicopter, and some sniper sequences. Well, on the first 2 modes you have more than 1 firing mode but the game doesn't tell you that, and you end up wondering why certain targets don't blow up, or why the game keeps telling you to do something that you're already doing.The actual FPS mode is sub-par, too. You can't choose what weapons you start the mission with, and you can only collect enemy weapons (not ammo to refill your one, unless it's the same model) or ask your friends for ammo, if they use the same one as yours.The action has so many little breaks because you either have to climb a 1.5 meters step with the help of a teammate, something exploded near you and you take a whole 15 seconds to get on your feet again, a whole lot of enemies arrived at a near position (so it's better to just look at them instead of firing, right?), the teammates has something to tell you, and so on. It's frustrating. The fact that the game is also an on-rail shooter, with no space for exploration and only one way from point a to point b, makes the SP experience feel so restricting and unsatisfying, that the fact that it only last 3 hours won't bother you so much at the end.Yes, you've read it right, 3 hours. That is about how much it took me to complete this game.It wasn't even so much fun for those 3 hours. The game plays the compassion card for all the soldiers that actually went into those places, risking their life for our freedom. Well I'm sorry, but there's already movies for that and when I buy a game I want a game, not a barely interactive movie. I'm sorry for those people and I really appreciate their work, and I think it's not honest to use their sacrifice to make bad games.The only thing that barely saves this game from being a complete disaster are the graphics. I get a solid 60fps in full-hd and everything at max, with vsync on, but it only looks good during daylight missions (like with most games anyway), and even there there's part of the graphics that is too blocky and/or has bad textures, but it's overall pretty good looking.The audio is a mess, though. The sound can barely be heard and you have to increase the volume at almost maximum in your audio equipment.Oh yeah, there's an additional game mode in SP, where you fight your way in a selected level for leaderboard score. Such fun.If only they added coop, that could have marginally saved this terrible game, but as it is, it's the usual EA game: just bad.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												It's shocking to me how hyped this game was, and how terrible it is. This game is generic to the max. It's like they looked at Battlefield and Call of Duty, distilled the basic features out of them, and stripped out any unique or iconic gameplay. It really feels like CoD with less recoil and no soul.I've tried both multiplayer and the campaign, but I'll be mostly reviewing the campaign. One thing I'll say about multiplayer - unless they've changed this, snipers start with no scopes, and you have to spend two hours getting spawn-killed and shooting one enemy per life to earn a crappy scope.Again, the campaign is uber-generic. You are a soldier in a special ops unit. You get briefed on objectives you don't care about, and are thrown into some fighting. Your guns have no recoil. Occasionally you get a slow-motion event.The missions aren't even put together well. There is a sniping mission where you work alongside a veteran sniper, an obvious attempt to copy the flashback mission in Modern Warfare, but executed so badly you'll be failing repeatedly while trying to figure out what he wants you to do. Everything has an extremely linear layout, but there are couple of places where it's still easy to get lost because the level doesn't flow well.Several missions are extremely frustrating or repetitive, or both. One mission has you sniping enemy soldiers on a hill. They're pretty far away, in some trees, and you can't see jack♥♥♥♥♥♥ You sit there and wait for your spotter to call out someone, try in vain to figure out where the target is, and then lose. But in the end you'll get it down because they keep spawning at a handful of locations.The most memorable moment for me was a mission where I was halfway through the level, and a scripted event had us pinned down by enemy MGs. An ally ordered me to provide covering fire with my own light MG so they could move up. But... I dropped my MG at the beginning of the level for a different weapon. So I tried to provide covering fire with my AK. Over and over. Time after time, I wasted entire magazines, but my allies didn't do anything. I tried shooting the enemy gunners, which should have been easy because they weren't very far away, but they were invulnerable. I looked all around the area but there was no LMG available. Finally I realized I could try to pop a grenade in the MG nest. That took a few tries to do without dying, but when I finally got a grenade in there, I was rewarded with... nothing.They seriously made a scripted event halfway through the level where you have to have an LMG to continue, but don't force you to keep the LMG from the beginning of the level and don't give you one when you need it. I had to replay the entire level with the LMG just to be able to pass that part.♥♥♥♥♥♥, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game design.

Posted: August 23, 2013
												EA's attempt to resurrect the Medal of Honor series by tapping into the modern war such as the fight in Afghanistan is almost universally judged as an also-ran that failed to distinguish itself from its chief rival, the COD: Modern Warfare series. And after playing it I can see why. The SP portion was designed apart from the MP portion (by different teams, even) and never quite tightly integrated. The SP campaign went for authenticity by recording actual soldiers and model missions that they went on, albeit somewhat dramatised, but the result, while authentic, seem to lack the "punch" or the dramatic tension that MW seem to deliver. The authenticity also reduced the enemy into ragtag group of poorly armed peasants that relied on numbers that just got lucky by pure amount of lead flying in your direction. You play several different people with bare transition between them which adds a bit to the confusion. All in all, the SP campaign offered all sorts of challenges, from standard cover shooter with flanking to rail-shooter sequence (the gunship sequence), to sniper alley (aka Whack-a-mole) to stealth escape, and turret defense (shoot anything that comes down that mountain). But it is primarily a shooter, albeit a rather... derivative one that broke no grounds.

Posted: April 16, 2012
												I was bored one afternoon and decided to give Medal Of Honor a shot as I really enjoyed the Mutiplayer Beta but was in the mood for a single player game. I expected to spend 15 minutes playing and then go on to something else. What I found was something amazing.MoH's single player is gritty and real. It embodies the harshness of the conflict and twines together the story of different squads interacting in the Afghan conflict perfectly. One moment you are waiting for evac and helicopters clear out the landing zone and then break off to hit another target - to which you transition to the next mission as that helicopter gunner.The audio is visceral. I got shot at in a village and flinched when a metal wall next to me was peppered with bullets. I can't remember the last time I've reacted to a game in such a way - and that is a great thing.MoH is a complete experience. I wish it lasted longer as I was able to complete the campaign in around 6 hours but it was worth every minute.

It's the first Medal of Honor I played, and I must say it has lessened my respect for all parties involved, including Humble for giving this more attention than it deserves.This game doesn't have any redeeming qualities I could come up with. You can feel that they tried pretty hard to clone Call of Duty (I mean, just look at the title, duh). Even the description on Steam is involuntarily hilarious. "...a relatively unknown entity of handpicked warriors"? Who writes stuff like that with a straight face?It's a persiflage of its own subject matter. The realistic enactment of war simply shouldn't be treated in a way like this, it's inadvertently offensive and cheap. Although I feel bad for giving a bad review for a game I paid almost zero $ for, I'm still desperate to warn everyone about giving this game a chance. If you have to, take Call of Duty on for another playthrough, it's still better after the third time than this is during any given 30 minutes of its awful campaign.Please note that I never played any Medal of Honor multiplayer, it may well be its singular redeeming quality, since there must be a reason for it to exist at all. So there. Hope you didn't buy this at anything more than a dollar.

Posted: August 26, 2015
												Medal of Honor (2010) actually wasn't as bad as the reviews for it were. I remember the largest criticism being in the choice to be able to play as the Taliban in the multiplayer. I didn't play the multiplayer, so that hasn't hindered my review of this game.In this reboot of the classic WWII series, the game is set in Afghanistan in very late 2001 and March 2002; being loosely based on Operation Anaconda, more specifically, the Battle of Shah-i-Kot and Battle of Takur Ghar. Takur Ghar is a mountain in the Shah-i-Kot Valley in Southeast Afghanistan where, at the time, Taliban and Chechan forces had dug themselves in with well over 500 forces encamped throughout the region. The game's plot revolves around a number of soldiers from the Navy SEALs and various regiments from the US Army, such as the US Rangers and the Aviation Regiment. While a number of the characters don't actually meet, they help each other out at certain points during the game, like at one point, the Rangers are pinned down and the Aviation forces swing in to help them out. Then you take over as the Aviation team to sweep the area. The story is rather simple, sweep the area of enemy forces and, at times, the Navy SEALs are actually gathering intelligence, scouting forces ahead for the Army. Not an amazing story, but the amount of research the team put forward when it came to the accuracy of how many casualties were actually lost on the US side during the battles and the specific locations and tracking the troops movement from real life to fiction was neat. Basically, I applaud the effort with the research even if the story is dry.Technical side, the games graphics are nice, but the AI on your side can get stuck at points and you might have to reload to a prior checkpoint, or worse, restart the whole level, that happened once. Some of the shadows bug out, but it wasn't that noticeable. Sound design is nice. Orchestra score is good, my only complaint that actually annoyed me was the soundtrack with like, Linkin Park. I hate Linkin Park. Seriously.My only other serious complaint is that at some points of the game, apparently every muslim is an enemy and end up being killed by the US Army. Sure enough, in the game, everone you encounter is an enemy except from the first mission where you drive through a town and see some people, like the guy herding his goats across the street. It was a pretty big village and maybe I half expected to see a woman or child out in the streets, but there weren't any, so it became apparent that everyone you'd encountered at that point would become your enemy, which was very much the case. There wasn't any perspective as to who the civilians were or could be. And even the Northern Alliance, the Afghan army that the US had allied with, barely make an appearance. Instead, they're friendly fired upon by an angry guy in Langley. That was just like a WTF moment. I know some of that happened in real life, but it seemed a bit overkill here.Still, a few minor complaints from an overall good FPS.8.0/10

Posted: February 4, 2015
												Download Size: Less than 9 gigabytesPlaytime: Less than 6 hours for single playerMedal of Honor (2010) was my intro to modern First Person Shooter games, so I go back and play it once in a while.  Despite the fact that the game plays nearly identically to the Call of Duty Modern Warfare games, Medal of Honor is actually from EA (makers of Battlefield). If you have this game, you probably got it as part of the Humble Origin Bundle from a year or so back (bunch of great games in that one). Like the Call of Duty games, MOH is split into Multiplayer and Single player installations, which means you can download just one or the other if you’re only planning to play through the campaign (like me). There is a separate Steam entry for each.The story of MOH follows a couple of Navy Seal teams in Afghanistan trying to root out Al Qaida / Taliban soldiers, mostly taking place in the mountains. You also switch to playing a member of a squad of Army Rangers for a couple of missions, and see the war from a different perspective. MOH is very story driven, and since you’re almost always in a squad, you can count on the other members of your team to support you when you’re under heavy fire. However if you get shot enough you’ll die and reload the checkpoint. Your team doesn’t “revive” you like in some other squad based games (Payday, Left 4 Dead). Gameplay is very much like Call of Duty Modern Warfare where you’re supposed to do most of the heavy lifting while the rest of your team kind of picks off a few enemies occasionally and provides ammo.MOH has the regenerating health system as expected in most modern first person shooters, with the screen edges turning red as you are taking damage and then clearing up if you don’t get shot for a few seconds. This means that a lot of the time you can risk making a run without cover and take some hits as long as you don’t die. You can also pick up the weapons of fallen enemies, though you should almost always keep your primary assault rifle (with the silencer when available).  An interesting gameplay element as mentioned above is that if you run low on ammo, you can always ask a computer controlled squad mate for more. I don’t remember this being available in many other first person games.Pros:+Pretty good graphics and engrossing story. If you like Call of Duty type shooter games, you should like MOH. I believe the game’s story is based on actual events.+A lot of gameplay variety. You can occasionally control aerial bombardment (as an attack helicopter pilot) or heavy direct fire aircraft (blowing up stuff with big guns!). The sniper/stealth sections are fun as well.Cons:-The game is really short. It can take less than 5 hours to beat the campaign if you’ve played the game before. For a game this short it takes up a lot of hard drive space.-There is at least 1 mission where it can be difficult to tell where you’re supposed to go. Your squad leader gives you an order and it isn’t immediately obvious what you’re supposed to do. Also, more than once I got stuck due to a game bug where an event didn’t trigger the way it was supposed to (marking a spot for air strike).Overall Medal of Honor is a fun game to go through in a weekend, and get a feel for what highly trained combat soldiers have to do for a living. If you’ve seen the recent Mark Wahlberg movie “Lone Survivor” this game has a similar feel (elite soldiers surrounded by enemies).Sequel info:MOH Warfighter is exclusive to EA Origin (no Steam version). I got my copy as a physical DVD so I didn’t have to go through the process of downloading it through Origin.Install size: Less than 20 gigabytesPlaytime: about 6 hours for single playerIn Warfighter, you play a new member of the same group of Navy Seals as in the first game, but with a few new additions to your team. The action takes place in several regions all over the world (Philippines, Middle East, etc.) unlike the first game, where you were in Afghanistan the whole time. There are also a bunch of cutscenes following a few characters in their “off-duty” life in the United States (kind of boring). The general plot of the game though, is chasing down terrorists before they execute their complicated plans of blowing stuff up.The game is very similar to the first MOH (as expected) and  it uses the Frostbite 2 game engine, which was featured in Battlefield 3. The graphics are VERY good and almost photo realistic at times. Unfortunately, this means that some computers may not be able to run the game at a decent frame rate. I found an issue where I would have horribly low frames per second at certain parts of the game, and it turned out that it was due to Origin downloading free map packs in the background (Zero Dark Thirty map pack was about 900 megabytes). When I stopped the downloads the game sped up. If you liked MOH1, you’ll like Warfighter.

Bottom line is for a game of this quality and if on sale I would recommend picking it up.  Cheers to MOH, always liked this games style even if it was not that popular.✓Recommended

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												In Medal of Honor, brotherhood is an unspoken bond of trust and companionship through acts of honor where failing to leave a soldier behind isn’t an option and risking one’s life for the fate of another is common. The idea of brotherhood created Medal of Honor’s storyline, and it is the best storyline I have ever played in a tactical FPS thus far. Just like any FPS fan, I too become overly ecstatic about this genre: I can talk hours upon hours about it, give you my critical opinions down to exquisite detail, and discuss creative and strategic ways to deceive opponents online. And so, I wasn’t expecting much out of Medal of Honor considering how popular titles like Modern Warfare 2 have already set a nearly untouchable standard for the FPS genre, and I couldn’t foresee any title that was able to compete with that.However, none have captured a story which is deep enough to really connect the player to the game’s storyline... until now. Although incredibly short, MoH’s campaign is done well and that’s an understatement. You play three different roles: Rabbit and Deuce, who are Tier 1 operatives, and Dante Adams, who is an Army Ranger. Usually, players are not able to become attached to the characters when the protagonist switches too many times and too quickly. But here, it works because it follows the concept of brotherhood mentioned above, covering what other popular shooters are missing in their campaign: a theme and the consistency of building a story around that theme.Furthermore, you’re thrown into a variety of scenarios. Everything that you could possibly imagine that takes place in a war is in MoH’s single-player campaign, such as being ambushed by waves of enemies or being nearly obliterated by a hidden bomb. And what would you do if you jumped out of a helicopter and only had your knife as a weapon? It’s full of intense action through and through—enough that you don’t want to put the controller down.Second, the game’s details are remarkable: Dust from the ground spits up from bullet fire, strobes continuously flash on your teammate’s shoulder when you switch to night-vision indicating who is a friendly, and even the sound of gunfire is different depending on where you are. Inside a wrecked plane, the bullets from a light machine gun has a tin-like sound with a subtle echo. Little details like these make you feel like you’re in a realistic battle.Another feature that emphasizes realism is the communication between you and your AI teammates. Throughout the story, you’re directly spoken to and you’re given orders without any abrupt pop-up hints of where to go next. You’ll hear things like, “Rabbit, take the path at your six…” and “Go loud on Rabbit”, indicating what your next move should be. This is extremely effective since you learn to listen closely as well as learn how to be part of a team, making you much more involved in the combat.Once you finish the campaign, Tier 1 mode is unlocked, where you aim to beat a level within a given time. That’s not all: There aren’t any checkpoints, so if you die, you start over; health regenerates slower; auto-aim assist and weapon’s crosshairs are disabled; and you cannot resupply on ammo from your allies. And need I emphasize the time limit? If you execute “skill kills”, like headshots and melee kills, then the clock temporarily stops. If the level is completed successfully, you earn a spot on the global leaderboards.Despite how amazing the story is, there are several flaws in its gameplay. There are few texture problems where some buildings or environments take time to load while AI characters, who are standing in place, shift abruptly. As for the AI, my teammates at times ran into my line of fire - I promise I was not actually shooting them. And the enemy AI is not much of a concern as they are terribly predictable. In turn, they do become challenging to fight against on certain levels where they attack in groups or waves. My AI teammates despite being drawn to my line of fire are also very effective in killing the enemy without any of my help.Medal of Honor’s minor weakness is its multiplayer. There are five different modes, three of which are objective-based: capturing and defending different points on the map. The other two consists of team deathmatch and hardcore. And let's not even go through the whole Taliban/Opposing Forces thing, or this review will never end. Just like single campaign, teamwork is crucial especially in objective games, like Objective Raid, where your goal is to defend two bases from the opposing team who has a goal to arm it and destroy it. In order to defend both bases, your team must spread out or the match could end in less than a minute. The gameplay itself is entertaining especially considering that several playlists offer up to 24 players, but just like the game modes, the maps lack variety. There are eight in total and they feature valleys, mountains, and marketplaces, which more or less look the same to me, and they all feature a monochromatic scenery, making the maps rather bland. I couldn’t understand how the single campaign has such diverse terrain with colorful scenery while the maps in multiplayer do not.Like I said in the beginning, I wasn’t expecting much out of Medal of Honor, but I was more than satisfied. While the multiplayer has its cons, it definitely has potential to be built into something more. The single-player campaign is enough to hold anyone through a gripping story with non-stop and fast-paced action and a trio of compelling characters. I should also mention that MoH is dedicated to America’s servicemen and I think it’s a job well done, no matter what the military bases say. Medal of Honor is one game you should be playing and one game that is now in competition with the rest.

												If you’re looking for a new campaign to crunch through, Medal of Honor (2010) will do for an evening. The campaign is serviceable, but very short. Some of the intros to missions are incredibly long and unskippable, which kills the replayability a bit. This also doesn’t leave much of the game left to actually play. The parts you do get to play are along very narrow buildings, valleys, etc. It’s a good campaign to play through once, but there are only one or two missions that are actually replay-worthy on their own.The characters all have cool sounding callsigns, but you’ll not really remember who is who, and they all become interchangeable.I’m hesitant to call any shooter video game “realistic”, but I’d say Medal of Honor comes closer than the other big names in the market right now.I personally enjoyed the soundtrack a lot, and found it added a lot to the game. I even purchased it separately.Lastly, one thing that swung my view of this game far into the positive (for me) was that the developers know bullet math. Most shooters acknowledge that if you have not emptied a magazine, then you don’t need to chamber a fresh round when reloading, YET the number of rounds available will only be those of the magazine. This is just a little pet peeve of mine, so I was super happy when I noticed that in Medal of Honor, the extra round is maintained when reloading.  Good job developers. Now why did that disappear in Warfighter?Anyhow, while I personally enjoyed this game, I have unique tastes, and I cannot in good conscience recommend it to a “general” gamer.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I went into Medal of Honor expecting another gritty, brown, cover-shooting FPS, clicking away until the brown terrorist hiding behind brown rocks stop moving. What you get is, well, that but not nearly as deary and grinding as I had anticipated and even did some things pretty well. Maybe it's because it's been a few years since I've played a single player modern military shooter.First off, the campaign is head scratchingly short. For a series that has always focused on single player it's a little puzzling that so much time and money was put into a 3-5 hour campaign. That being said, short is better than long and grindy. There is a good mix of stealth based and all out war game play, with vehicle and sniper sections scattered through out that keep things fresh. You jump between three view points that tie together nicely whcih prevents the transitions from being jarring. One of the things that I thought they did well was conveying the uncertainty of who is a target and who is a civilian, or even a friendly. I do think they missed an opportunity to put those decisions on the player, as most of those situations occur in either scripted sections or cut scenes, but still, it didn't go unnoticed.There were a few more details that helped lift this game a bit above mediocre. The guns felt varied and solid, although the shotgun is overpowered, and headshots look and sound satisfying. My favorite detail was the sound design. There's this really cool thing when you're standing near a squad member who's speaking and you can hear their voice both through the radio and normally. It doesn't actually effect anything but it's a nice detail that's realistic and helps with immersion and makes me wonder why I haven't heard it in more games.There's no reason to run out and buy this at full price but if modern FPSs are your thing or you get the chance at a good price it's worth a quick play through. A note on the value: I didn't play more than just loading into a couple of games but the multiplayer is still up and running and there were players. You may need to go into the settings file and force the DirectX to version 9. There's also what they call Tier 1 mode which is just leader boards for completing the campaign levels while hitting or beating various statistical goals (time, accuracy, melee kills, etc).

Posted: January 3, 2014
												I was enjoying the first couple hours of this game. Then the arbitrary, no matter what you do you're screwed plots began, intermixed with the cliche'd slow-motion "You just got blown up" scenes. I despise linear games with predestined outcomes, and I really hate getting deep into a game, then no matter how well I play, or even how poorly, my character is destined to be captured/killed/blown-up/eaten by aliens, etc. I played all of the original MOH games years ago. I have to say I'm not impressed with how this one has evolved to become like COD, a bunch of short chapters played by different characters with different names.  That being said, the game doesn't suck. It's just written like many games are these days. "We want you to see how GREAT we are at plots, so we're going to force your character into mandatory actions".  Oh and, as for the flamers and fan-boys who can't bear to hear any negative comments, blow me! I paid my money, I'm entitled to my opinion. I've been gaming for 30 years so I think I've seen enough games to differentiate between good, mediocre and bad. I'll still give this a thumbs-up, but the game could definitely be better.  If you like games with areas that are like the old side-scrollers, then you won't mind sitting back for anywhere from 30 seconds to two minutes as your character does things that you can't control. As for me, I think it REALLY interrupts the gameplay. I doubt I'll by MOH Airborne on steam. I have it on DVD, and I really don't want to see what they've done to it.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
MEDAL OF HONOURA po-faced version of Call of Duty without any of the overblown action scenesRating 4/10A competent but incredibly dull trek around Afghanistan. It takes itself far too seriously for what it essentially a heavily scripted action game. You could say it's like the game version of the film Act of Valour. It's not all bad and there a couple of good set pieces which are effectively a last stand scenario reminiscent of the best Call of Duty set pieces however more often than not it's a repetitive slog through dull mountain ranges shooting at brain dead wack a mole enemies. There is nothing particularly new and fresh about Medal of Honour just a feeling of déjà vu, you've played this game 10 times before, it's just had different names.It's also incredibly short, clocking in at around 3 hours for the single player campaign and that's taking your time on the hardest difficulty. Just when you think the game is about to start it ends, it feels rushed much like the disappointing ending to Kane and Lynch Dog Days.

												I know that CoD gets a lot of flak and most of it is well deserved I admit. But it was never as terrible as this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥at least. No matter how bad Modern Warfare series ♥♥♥♥ed up, they will always be better than this imitation.Lets take a look at the long list of cons:- Weapons have no weight and feel to them. You never get the feeling of pressuring the trigger of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ PKM and your hits, they simply don't matter. You won't get the satisfaction you get when you lined up headshots in MW.- Story is non-existant. "These are the bad guys, we are the good guys. Kill them."- They added a long♥♥♥♥♥ATV driving+stealth section in the game, but ATV feels like a toy car. It simply stops right away when you press "S", it won't be affected by the rocks on the road.- Stealth is much more worse. The enemy will look you right in the eyes and won't see you, because you're supposed to be hidden at that moment.- You cannot avoid game logic. The game wants you to go to some point, you have to. Do you want to go back because there was a nice sniper spot there? Too ♥♥♥♥ing bad loser, the door you kicked in and broke off from its hinges is fully repaired and for some reason you can't kick it down again. The only thing that works right in Afghanistan is its door makers it seems.- Enemies spawn constantly if you're "not supposed to" kill them. And in some places they respawn right in the same spot, right in front of your eyes. Even if you're unloading a big fat PKM upon the spawn point. Hilarious. - Too damn easy. I am just a decent FPS player, not that good, not that bad, just around the average. I have to say it, hardest difficulty in this game is no better than playing MW1(CoD4) on lowest difficulty.- Glitches. Too damn many glitches. The reason I stopped playing was some glitch that kept me from progressing. If I had a way of finding the chapter name, so I could look for a solution, but there wasn't any indication of it. I thought the game isn't worth the trouble.- I have read that the game ends in 4 hours. EA, DICE and Danger Close (Who the ♥♥♥♥ are these guys?) just went somewhat indie with this game and made two interns and a cow to work on this game I assume.If you want a decent story (although they ♥♥♥♥ed it up with MW3 I'd say) with modern warfare, your first choice should be the Modern Warfare (Pripyat... a better mission than this whole game combined) trilogy, this should be the last.Terrible/10

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												I'm having some fun playing this but other times I just want to get to the end. The characters are boring. Seems like everybody is a hardened white commando from about the same background and with the same attitude and feelings about everything except for one black commander who might as well be white and one white general or CIA guy or something who should be a lot better actor. The sound is bad. There's lots of err... homoerotic commando whispering in your ear as you stealthily follow the one and only path to "penetrate" your next objective like Dorothy for instance. I like it but the whispering voice sounds the same way no matter if that commando is in front of you, behind you or fifty feet in front of you. And your name keeps changing as you switch identities for no apparant reason. The cities aren't much bigger than farms. The guy directing you often tells me to do things but I have trouble following his instructions. It helps to press H so that your objective lights up for a little while. Its not really that important because there aren't any different ways to go but it took me some time to figure that out. Quite a few times I've been unable to progress and been forced to restart a mission. I'm often annoyed with the game choosing my weapon. Can't I be allowed to make any decisions? I've played other games that allow me to pick weapons  and choose paths and my name. That's how I prefer it. This game doesn't allow a lot of freedom in allowing you to pick what you'll do next or how you'll do it and its very repetitious. There's one mission where you are taking cover in some crumbling mud shack and the enemy streams in forever down the hills around you. It just gets tiring picking them off. Hard to believe they would waste that many guys on that pathetic tactic but I suppose it could happen. What's going on with that Barret sniper rifle view? Its like they mounted a camera on the back of a camel walking on rocky terrain in high winds.The graphics are good and there's a lot of action. Its not as good as taking a walk but its better than raking leaves. This game is not sleep inducing. It'll tire you out but it will also make you feel restless and and angry. If you need to fall asleep I recomend Eurotruck simulator.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Hi, everybody!OK, So I have just come out of a 30h stint of Dishonoured, so I'm going to make a couple of comparisons to that here.OK So the good/normal stuff.It's a Rail Shooter = There is only one way to progress one possible direction of events can unfold. This is good in that it directs the story in the direction that the writers want it to go. I like rail shooters, Half Life is a rail shooter, by definition.The Shooting controls.YAY SOMEONE GOT IT RIGHT! The way it is set up, by default, is how I, and other pro FPS players, have our controls (mostly).Crouch and sprint whilst the button is depressed, not on toggle. Rifle Zoom on Rcklick, also on toggle. WOOT WOOT! Really this is only a little thing as it can usually be changed in the keyboard settings, but I didn't have to change it, for once. Would have been nice if melee was mapped to F, tho. (usually I would have it on E, but that was needed for peeking, which didn't feel as good as the Dishonoured's version)The Stealth/Knifing - there were about 6 opportunites to employ this, if you wanted to. Which is reasonable for a gun-focussed campaign. The stealth itself was only OK... you had to kill in the prescribed order, if you went off the script, everyone is alerted and it devolves into a gun fight. I also feel that the enemies hit harder during the stealth sections if you stuffed it up and started a gun fight, as an incentive to do it the way the writers wanted you to. You could run behind someone and they would not hear you. But stealth the wrong guy (or the right guy in the wrong order) and he'd alert the whole base.Health bar - was a fast-regenerating red mist that surrounds the vision, similar to CoD, I believe, but better in that it only took a couple of hits (3?) before I was restarting at the checkpoint. Good and bad.The mechanic suited the game andt he fast-paced storyline.Enemies - these would flank and attack, and dive for cover, the AI seemed fine, their accuracy was acceptable. Exept the snipers.Sniping (Barret sections)These were pretty good. You had wind, bullet travel time, and an IR camera to deal with.everything was there except the recoil. Oh there is one bit where you are sniping and your spotter is calling shots. He does a fairly hopeless job of it. and their snipers are useless shots. Then they had Dragonov's VS our Barret.Run-And-Gun (the story proper)Mostly fine, sections of running to find cover, picking your shots, and not getting shot or grenaded in the process. You can always ask your allies for more ammo if you're out, too - which is kinda nice. There are some points (you will realise them when it happens) where eventually you realise the enemies have infinite respawn, and the nex event is actually triggered by you moving up closer to the enemy stronghold.  I didn't really like that mechanic. Nor did I like the absolute reliance on Air support to take out dug-in targets such as AA turrets and mortar fire. What would the Rangers do without the Airfoce, I wonder? Hmmm... drop a grenage instead of a signal flare, I imagine.Story Telling:I didn't like how you were constantly being told parts of the story through different Character's eyes. At least, I didn't like how it was done in this game. Usually when this is done, it creates some extra layer of depth to the game, due to the new character having a different mechanic, such as Raven in MSG2  Where you swithced from gun play to sword play. In this, when you change guys, you swap your M4 for (I dunno, some other full auto assault rifle. I plead ignorance). There wasn't really enough difference in each character to truely make each one feel unique. It really was just more of the same as the other guy buy now they are calling me something different when they talk to me.The story: (no spoilers)Was a nod to the boys on the ground, their trials, and their hardships. This was done in the outworking of the story, quite well. not really a spoiler, but if you don't want any clues about the game story at all... "Bullets or bones? Bones heal... Jump!" would be my favourite line in the movie/game. Their desperation felt sincere, That's a rare thing in gaming story lines. I feel like it was a pity the game was only 5h long, but it told the story they wanted it to, without drawing it out - which maight actually leave you feeling cheated if it went on 'forever' and that ending was the one that you got. it was a good length for the story that was told. Just the game itself was well done and felt a bit short, if only because I wanted a bit more of the exellent game play, There are more things I could comment on, I guess, like the part where you play the Apache Gunner, which served well if only to break the gameplay up and provide some variety. but really, everything about this game was good to OK, and worth a play through. I think I got this either for $4 on special, or in a bundle, So i can't complain about the price. But I have never bought a game (OK I might have once at some point) that wasn't at least 66% off, so don't ask me about paying retail for it.Final verdict, If you are an FPS fan, It's worth a run, on at least normal difficulty. I'm sure If I played this  on easy I could go all Rambo on it and mulch the game in a couple or three hours.I miss the freedom of Dishonoured. Guess what I'm off to play? (Yes, I have Ghost/No Kills on every level)
