content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												This review is for the game ''Medal of Honor'',a first-person military shooter video game,developed by the video game company Danger Close Games(Single-player) and EA Digital Illusions CE(multiplayer).It was published by Electronic Arts and released in October 12,2010 for NA and October 15,2010 for Europe.The game uses the Unreal Engine 3 for the single player campaign and the Frostbit 1.5 for the multiplayer mod.The game is available for Microsoft Windows,Playstation 3 and Xbox 360.Single player-campaign plotThe campaign,of the thirteenth installment of the Medal of Honor series,takes place during the first days of the invasion of Afghanistan,in 2002.The story might be based on on the events that took place during Operation Anaconda that occured in March 2002,approximately six months after 9/11.In the game you will get to experience warfare that happened in reality like the seizing of Bagram Airfield,the Battle of Takur Ghar and the Battle of Shah-i-Kot.Throughout the game you will be exchanging roles between the Navy SEAL DEVGRU ''Rabbit'',a Delta Force sniper code-named ''Deuce'',Ranger Dante Adams and the Apache helicopter gunner Brad Hawkins.Apart they will face great battles and will have to overcome great obstacles in order to protect their country,their freedom and their well-being.MultiplayerMultiplayer is really rich in weapon customization,perk unlockables,achievements,statistics and ribbons giving the sense of fulfillment to the player while playing multiplayer.Sadly the multiplayer is quite dead already.Unfortunately no more that 100-200 gamers play daily.RecapMedal of Honor series used to be Electronic Arts' flagship.Unfortunately interest got lost since EA focused more on the development was focused on creating and expanding the Dragon Age series,the Dead Space series,the Crysis series and especially the Battlefield series,whom today are EA's flagship.Pros+Beautiful graphics+Interesting fast paced storyline,sometimes heartbreaking+Exciting and easy to use shooting mechanismsCons-Deceased multiplayer-Linear mission based storyline(too linear for my taste)Q:Do i recommend this game?A:Depends.If you want to explore the single player campaign and progress through the Medal of Honor universe absolutely yes.If you buy it for the Multiplayer mod do not bother you'll be playing alone or with a bunch of 12 year olds.P.S I didn't refer much on the Plot section because i didn't want to spoil the game to you.Buy it and play it thoroughly.Support the developers.Electronic Arts thank you for this game.

												SP: The story is pretty powerful, as it's loosely based on the real events of the Battle of Roberts Ridge. It's a gripping story and the cutscenes do it justice. The gameplay however is very monotonuous. The Taliban fighters just seem to come at you like a wave of zombies. When they shoot from cover, it's like your're playing one of those flash games where the enemies pop up at exactly the same place in a periodic manner. This makes the enemies feel very unreal and almost laughable. You also don't have any room to diverge from the beaten track, it's a completely linear shooter like CoD.MP: The unlock system just simply and plainly sucks. content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												For the price point of 20 dollars- I'd say this game is just about what you pay for. If it was another cent more it would be getting a no instead of a yes recommendation. ... actually- an edit here. After typing through this and realizing just how very much I did not enjoy this game, I cannot give it a recommendation at this price point. If it's on sale for 10 dollars, sure pick it up. Otherwise I'd suggest passing on it.Aside from the several game-breaking bugs I encountered while playing through the campaign, setting me back ~30 minutes or forcing me to make the conscious choice to restart the level completely due to an inability to stop crouching, jump, or run... the gameplay as a whole was rather unenjoyable. It felt almost like an indie game... a B-movie among video games I suppose. There were parts where it was damn near impossible to find what you were supposed to shoot at, there was a section where you had to use "hellfire missiles" but it did not tell you how, leaving me stuck at that section until I finally looked through all the control bindings to find them on some crazily arbitrary key when they could have simply used right mouse button... The enemy AI wasn't even lacking. It was nonexistent. All the enemies shared the same ~8 models/textures, and the same type of enemy would always run into the same exact position wave after wave until you got your air support to blow it all to hell for you. This is essentially 90% of the game. The other 10% is the game forcing you to stealth through some areas even though being the super soldier any FPS game innately makes you, you could just plow through easily.The actual sounds of gunfire were pretty good, but the MUSIC... god. You know how all games have their OSTs- and then at that one point of the game where everything gets real or goes wrong, you have the really feelsy ones that make the scene feel epic? And how EVERY game does it? Well it might seem like a broken record, but there's a reason things are like that. Because it's a winning formula- it works. Unfortunately the people making Medal of Honor decided to try to fix what was not broken. EVERY single track felt like it was trying to be that "epic scene" to make the game feel 100x more exciting than it actually was. When all the music tries to compete for sounding amazing, nothing feels special.The story. Full of holes, nearly nonexistent... without spoiling anything too much, when big scenes happen I just don't CARE. You don't get any backstories. You don't get any personality building. It's just you're there, you do stuff, and the game ends pretty damn abruptly. There's also a very strange "ending after the ending" that made no sense whatsoever. I have no clue if it was hinting towards the next game or what, but it was extremely out of  place and even further undermined the "big scene" of the ending.The design was also sub par. As I said all the enemies seemed to share the same few models and textures. The environment all felt the same and the map design was poorly laid out for progression- I constantly also ran into invisible bumps that made me stub my toe and unable to move somewhere I clearly should be able to.Overall if I had to score this- I'd give it a 4/10. At least the credits give you a link to donate to a good cause...? Maybe this game was supposed to be promotional for that? If it was- it shouldn't have been. It'd be much more effective if a GOOD game were to be used for that end.EDIT: One last edit. There might be ONE thing this game "did right". If I had to take a guess- this might be what war actually feels like (to some extent). Everything feels confusing. There's nothing pointing you in the right direction. It's chaos all around you. Everything looks and feels the same. Unfortunately that just doesn't make for a fun video game for the masses that have been raised on the modern FPS games we have now. I feel like it's possible to get the same "realistic" (again this is an assumption of maybe their goal with the game) experience while still keeping it fun and interesting. I never did mention- the guns feel horridly inaccurate. I've shot guns; they're not pinpoint like in other games, but they're not THIS bad either.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This is a well done FPS that somehow went under the radar during a time when the Call of Duty and Battlefield franchises began  saturating the market. The single player campaign is short, but it takes players through a series of fun and exciting missions, based on real world events during the 2001 invasion of Afghanistan, specifically Operation Anaconda. I was impressed with the authenticity that went into the game. Alot of the terminology is something that military folks might only understand. The weapons were done well, and there is a good assortment of hardware for players to get their hands on. Overall, I think Danger Close did a great job with the SP portion but I wish they would've also done the MP portion. DICE (Battlefield), for some reason, was contracted to develop the MP portion. In my opinion, the MP is just stale and too much like Battlefield. Many of the features that are available in SP are not available in MP. Weapons and damage model in MP are also horrible. Hit detection, is most notably, the worst I've seen in any game. Would not recommend MP.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												In the summer of 2011, I made the horrific mistake of buying this game just for early access to the Battlefield 3 beta (also, BF3 turned out to be a disappointment that drove me back to BC2).The single player campaign is basically a crappier Call of Duty. Call of Duty may be rehashed garbage but at least its campaigns are entertaining enough to keep me engaged to the end. I could not say the same with the first hour or so of this awful game. Also, why the heck does this not use Frostbite for single player? That would have kept me interested a little longer. Btw, I heard that the campaign was even worse in the Warfighter sequel that proved embarrassing for EA.The multiplayer mode uses a limited-destruction version of Frostbite (WTF, DICE?). It's a horrible console port with boring maps, few vehicles, and no mod tools for the community to make their own maps (as is the trend these days, sadly).On the technical side, the graphics are nothing to be impressed about. Optimization is passable, but won't make up for the very unimpressive gameplay.Please do not buy this game. If you want a brainless single player shooter from a greedy publisher, then play Modern Warfare 2 or 3. If you want an atrocious multiplayer experience, go download the blandest, worst-rated user-created maps from Counter-Strike community websites.P.S. content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
-Quick Review-Medal of Honor (2010) not to be confused with Medal of Honor (1999) on the PlayStation. Medal of Honor was released on 2010 by EA (Electronic Arts). Medal of Honor takes place in Afghanistan, and was actually developed under the inspiration of American Special Forces.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: The Medal of Honor storyline will have you bouncing back and forth between four different characters, all the while trying to keep up with the unfolding conflict between the USA and with a group similar to the Taliban.The game starts with you playing as a character from a Navy SEAL named “Rabbit”. You will also play once as an Apache gunner, then you alternate between a Delta Force Sniper and and Army Ranger, and finally ending the game from Rabbits perspective.


Guiding a missile - uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Medal of Honor(TM) Single Player
By: Atratzu




Let me say, this story is just a mess. Within the first twenty minutes of the game, you start switching between characters. There are games that can successfully switch playable characters and you comprehend the story being told, but none of the characters are memorable to drive this method. Honestly, the only two teams I remember participating on were the Navy SEAL's and the Delta Force Sniper group. Everyone else is a blur of “and then we did that”.While the story was interesting, and at times upsetting, (as it can be, when an outsider in a comfortable desk is giving orders which make no sense to the boots on the ground...) the story narrative is hard to follow because of all the character switching, making the story completely tangled and forgettable. Which is sad, as it could have been fantastic.


Dirt bikes! - uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Medal of Honor(TM) Single Player
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: The controls are pretty basic as far as most FPS's go. You can alternate between a Primary weapon, a secondary, and a pistol. You also have a melee attack for close fighting, and grenades.Depending on whom you're playing as, you have different weapons. For example the seals used a M16-modded rifle, and secondary was a sniper. While in contrast the Delta Sniper group all had silencer modifications on pistols and snipers.While fighting you can swap out, or pick up weapons... ...but again, that's a footnote and just an expected feature in FPS's.


Ground Combat Sample - uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Medal of Honor(TM) Single Player
By: Atratzu




Achievements: There are no Steam Achievements within Medal of Honor. However, in multiplayer there are “Awards” and unlockables as you level up and obtain “skill”.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528129615Price: Medal of Honor is priced at $19.99, I came by my copy from a Humble bundle years ago. The story mode (or “Campaign”) will last about 4 hours, probably less depending on the difficulty you play at and how hard you push forward.There is mutliplayer, but I'll add a section to my review to discuss multiplayer features more in depth. Unless you play multiplayer, $19.99 is far too high a price.Multiplayer: I logged on several times to see how the community was doing, and naturally there are a few people still playing the game. But there was only one game going actively, the rest were empty.The Multiplayer is what you would expect: you run around, help capture objectives, fill enemies with bullets, get murdered by the guy who's played nonstop since release... 'ya know, the “norms”.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528129217As you complete multiplayer games, you get experience errr excuse me “skill” points (which acts the same way as experience points in other games), you rank up the classes you've been playing, which unlocks bonuses for that class.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=528129359History: I can't complete this review without saying that I admire the Medal of Honor series. The first game I played was the original Medal of Honor released by DreamWorks Interactive in 1999 for the PlayStation.Looking back, the story from the 1999 version wasn't so great or interesting. However, it's easier to forgive because of the limitations on hardware at that time. It's a bit more difficult to forgive when a game was released in 2010.While I do admire the series, it is always been 100% biased for the United States Agenda. (at times I feel falls close to “propaganda”) At least the Medal of Honor series treats the soldiers respectfully and honorably. In the end I care about the soldiers, not the power hungry politicians and governments fueling the wars and death.Conclusion: Medal of Honor was a disappointment, and I really hate to say that. The story was short, it has emphasis on online content and leaderboards, the story was terribly presented, the gameplay was mediocre at best. From a big name like “Medal of Honor”, there's a fairly long and impressive heritage, making this game's failures all that much more disappointing.Did the game work? Yeah. Is there still some Multiplayer? Yeah. Can you play and shoot up people? Yeah. What sets this game apart? Nothing. You can take it or leave it. For 20 dollars get a game that actually has a story. If you want online competitive play, go grab a game like Call of Duty, Counter Strike, Team Fortress, there are many choices of FPS which still has a community.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527199532------Edits and updates------Edit/Update October 03, 2015:A very hardy thankyou to Angfucious for spell checking and grammar correcting this piece before I posted it. I wanted to make sure I was as articulate and spot on as possible.

												A ridiculously railroaded, bland, unpolished corridor shooter.The AI is non existent. Enemies just run to their designated spot and shoot in your general direction. Your teammates always run into your gunfire and grenades. The gameplay is insipid with plenty of point and click games and turret sections. content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												Medal of Honor is a bland, shallow and uninspired first person shooter very clearly developed and marketed to cash in on the success that the Call of Duty: Modern Warfare series was seeing at the time, and in that regard it falls flat on its face. Lets start with the positives. The graphics are pretty good for 2010 and the scene when you're fighting your way up a mountain while an AC-130 gunship fires on targets in the valley below was pretty cool.Now that that's out of the way.MoH is a short, boring corridor shooter occasionally broken up by boring turret sections. Your whole squad are walking ammo boxes that you can request ammo from whenever you get low, so ammo conservation and battlefield scavenging do not exist. The shooting is bland and the guns feel weak. There is hardly any weapon variety and almost no enemy variety.Friendly and enemy AI is generally bad. Enemies stand in the middle of open ground during firefights facing the wrong direction. Almost every time I saw a friendly AI throw a grenade it hit whatever he was using as cover, even during a scripted sequence when one of your squad members uses a grenade to clear a cave entrance. This got me killed more than once. Friendlies will CONSTANTLY run into your fire, blocking enemies and complaining about friendly fire, although as far as I could tell, you can't actually harm them. On multiple occasions scripted sequences would break and require me to load the previous checkpoint. The checkpoints were badly placed and dying would often result in having to replay long portions of the mission and watch unskippable scripted sequences all over again.All of the characters are the same generic, bearded tier 1 operator that contemporary shooters are known for. By the end of the game I didn't know anything about any of the characters or their personalities, which wouldn't be so bad if the game weren't constantly trying to make you feel comradery with your squad and to empathise with their struggle.There are a very limited number of graphics options and the FOV is so low that I had to sit a few metres away from my screen in order to not feel nauseous.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												So... Medal of Honor... Infamous for it's "racism" and overall mediocre presentation.I'll just tell it how it is. The gunplay feels good only if you score headshots. Otherwise the sound design and the feel of the gun leaves much to desire. The story starts off really weak and continues on the same level for the most part. The last hour of the game though is really great and emotional. And I think that's the reason why a few of these people reviewing here claim that the story is amazing. Some complain that the story is too short (4-6 hours, depending on your skill) and to them I'll say "What are you talking about?" This is perfect length. It shows an operation and you get enough. Anything longer would feel just like filler and it'd get boring.The multiplayer is dead. Don't buy it for this. I had the chance to play it when it was still a body that was twitching and in all honesty, you're not missing out on much. The graphics even now look beautiful. The soldiers that are currently deployed still say that the game looks like the world actually does and I have to admit, that's pretty impressive then.The main issue that I have with this game is the FOV. I tried changing it but to no avail. It's a constant 60 FOV or so and it's pretty disgusting because of it.The options menu is mediocre, but it still offers a few options in terms of windowed mode, resolution and some graphics changes. It runs fine as well.Overall5/10A good surprise, considering the reviews.(All games start at a 5/10 and move upwards/downwards based on pros and cons)

Posted: August 24, 2016
												Dull, on rails, and completely sans story. The gunplay feels weak, enemies don't react to shots or even the player, as they will walk straight past you to get to their scripted spot before taking action. Allies do everything for you. Even on "Hard", you needn't fire a shot thanks to the overbearing teammates. The only plus to the gunplay is that the normally distant and hollow sounding weapons change in timbre when you reach the end of a magazine. And to completely describe the story, it starts off with one squad trying to find an informant, who tells them that there are enemies nearby and something about a daughter, and that's it. Subsequently playing as different characters, you are just dropped into a warzone to do fighting towards some people who are pointing their fighting at you until two of the player characters meet up at the end. There's no spoilers, because there's no plot. They have no reason to do any of this apart from being told to do the fighting in one direction until the game decides to stop mid-level, entirely without climax or warning, and roll credits.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												That wasn't fun at all. (Single player review, normal difficulty, This review doesn't include multiplayer or Tier 1 mode.)My entire playthrough of this game which was a short 4 hours of my life, I didn't enjoy this game at all. I liked and appreciated small things in this game. But that was it, I expected a generic shooty game, and a generic shooty game it was.With a disgustingly short campaign mode anyways.It was 4... let that sink in. FOUR hours long, probably because this is like a Call of Duty thing where people actually only buy it for the Multiplayer, which I can understand. But dear god. FOUR hours. I was watching the end credits before I knew it and all I could think was "no. No this can't ALREADY be over." But yeah. IIIIITTTT was.Anywho, the gameplay. It's a generic shooty game, I don't really know what else to say. You have gun, you use said gun to kill hostile people. You win game. That's pretty much it.There was very little gun variation, the maps were all boring to me, the combat was boring, missions were boring, nothing new, all boring.The things I appreciated in this game was some small gun-attention details, like how if I reload with a bullet still in the chamber, my full bullet count is one over the typical full-magazine reload. And I appreciated how relaxed the voices are in the game. Because in real life, that's how it is. No gravely-speaking men all the time all angry and always eager to show who's south pole's bigger on the mic or on the battle-field for that matter.Butttt... yeah. Really all I have to say nicely about this game, it was a boring disappointment to me from start to end. I was hoping, that even though I expected a generic shooter. That it'd be a little bit more different of a approach to a fps shooter, but i'm sorry I did.The thing that probably annoyed me the most is when they threw me in a helicopter in a first-person camera in the drivers seat. I was so excited. I thought I was going to be flying that thing around for that mission. Nope. It was a rollercoaster ride where I just left-clicked on people and sometimes right-clicked if they were being extra mean than their ak-47 wielding fellows.I really don't want to write a honest review that covers the bases for this game. If you want a shooty game, just go get the next CoD or something, it'll have at least zombies or aliens or something. And endless multiplayer matches. As opposed to an older title like this.Anyways, thanks for reading. I don't really blame you if this didn't help your decision to make a purchase or not. Sorry about that, but have a good day.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												I've been playing games for over 25 years now and I can safely state that this new interpretation of MoH is the worst FPS I have ever experienced.- Story and dialogue consist of either a) military gibberish that is probably supposed to sound cool and badass but comes off as nothing but incomprehensible and boring or b) cringeworthy and corny exchanges of either patriotic or SUPERRRRRR TOUGH lines. My favorite? Early on you rescue an Afghan, but your men aren't sure if they can trust him:Grunt A: For all we know he set us up a trap. We can't trust this guy!Grunt B: You're right. Hurr durr.Tariq (the Afghan): I have a daughter, I want her to live in freedom.All grunts together: Oh, ok, now we trust you. You're cool.- Your playing field is EXTREMELY limited despite many areas appearing to be open. So you're just blocked by measly small boulders and the likes. Some you can hop over, some you can't. Have fun finding out which are which.- Despite the pipe-shaped levels it is sometimes way too easy to miss the exact spot you need to step on in order to trigger the next event.- Occasionally these triggers are even bugged, forcing you to reload from a checkpoint. Once, for example, my men told me to secure a hut...in a village full of huts that basically all look the same. So I approach each and every one multiple times to no avail. After I (on purpose) blew myself up with a grenade suddenly my men didn't just stop, but pushed on.- Moments that are supposed to stand out are even worse than the general gameplay. Directing missiles and whatnot from far away for minutes is pure valium; sniping is tedious and the game obviously acknowledges it by pushing you towards your targets if you can't find them within the low resolution, all-lookalike mountainsides; and that part where you and your men take cover inside a hut, fending off dozens of Taliban that reduce your cover to little more than a few bricks would even be too ridiculous for a Bugs Bunny cartoon.- mission objectives just kind of pop up all the time and are marked as completed all out of a sudden. You never feel like you're actually accomplishing anything, instead merely pushing forward and letting the game do the rest. And if you ever do get lost because of the game's bugginess, the mission objectives don't give off any useful information as to what to do exactly.- Press F to get pulled up a small ledge by your buddy? What for? It doesn't add ANYTHING to the gameplay and it feels completely out of place when your men can take the same ledge on their own easily. It's just supposed to show off some sort of comradery. Woo, these guys are so cool...- which leads to another downer: None of the soldiers you meet is charismatic or memorable. They either come off as complete♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that don't give a damn about the values they are supposed to be fighting for but merely loving the fight itself, or they are so forgettable, you won't even remember their names for a minute.- Combat simply doesn't feel good. Weapons don't pack a punch and often you're left wondering if you hit a guy and whether he's just hurt or dead.- Not a single moment in the game sticks out.- a mere 4 hours long- even the ending sucks. The moment I realized the game was about to end was when, ironically, one of your men says "This is not how it ends.". The rescue mission right at the end of the campaign is probably meant to be some big highlight. Some huge event the whole tension is building up to. Only, it doesn't work that way at all. It just felt like I was in the middle of the game, not like I was nearing the end. Rarely have I seen such an anticlimactic ending, which is made even worse with a stupidly blunt cutscene wrapping things up. Supposedly, teh mountainside is void of enemys (they even outright tell you so), but still we see them bombed to smithereens. Why? Maybe because the director said he'd need some more explosions. And what about the brief segment showing a busy street in peaceful Afghanistan? I haven't got a clue. Maybe worst of all is the Linkin Park song playing afterwards. I like Linkin park, that's not the problem. My issue is that it seems highly out of place. It feels like the song went right over the guy's head who was responsible for licensing songs.How about some other slapstick moments the campaign despite being so short is loaded with?- Airplanes delivering airstrikes magically fly straight through mountains popping back into sight at the other end.- You are supposed to mark a bunker but it won't work? Oh, silly you, what the game really meant for you to do is to mark some nondescript boulder a few metres away from the bunker. Don't worry, the airplanes are still going to hit the bunker, not the boulder.- Your highly specialized teammate opens up a door to a dark tunnel? I'm sure he'll do it carefully, taking cover and using flashlights or thermovision. Oh, too bad, he just stands in the entrance - upright - and shouts "oh, it's so dark in there" only to get shot.Bottom line: Horrible game that is in no way realistic, but tries its best to convey such an image and thus sacrifices gameplay. So in the end it gets neither right.At least the so-called Tier 1 mode is a nice idea. Here, you replay the SP missions, aiming for fast times, earning medals in the process. If only the gameplay mechanics would make for a better foundation.

Posted: June 13, 2014
												Medal of Honor is, without any exaggeration, the most bland game I have ever seen in my entire life. It is repetitive, there is no story, gameplay is extremely basic and no feeling of progression as you go through the extremely short (5 hours in my case) game.The game is set entirely in Afghan tundra, with the exception of one urban level and another one set in an airbase and although  tundra is not a common environment in videogames, it is extremely overused here. Gameplay consists of simple first-person shooter action broken up by vechile sections. There was nothing in that respect that I haven't seen before. The story was so extremely uninteresting that I forgot it in it's entirety inbetween playing it and writing this review and although that was some time, I can say with certainity that there was no thing going on for the entire duration of the game. I was simply doing stuff without any form of greater context, so my memory of it all is now a miasma of brown deserts with equally brown-uniformed men trodding around while firing the same boring guns at other brown men. The only thing I remembered was one nice moment where you were given the impression that you would be overwhelmed by the enemy in a lengthy standoff, but the opportunity for the game to do something interesting is wasted when you are saved by a helicopter at the last moment. But without doubt the worst moment in the entire story aspect is when I didn't realise the game was over untill the end credits appeared. I seriously was just playing a mission as difficult or interesting as all the other ones untill all of a sudden a cutscene came up where I found some guy dead who I had to rescue since the moment the game had reached 50% of it's runtime. Then the game just stopped. In other words, a story thread that only spanned part of the game was resolved and for some reason the game took the moment to run off in it's entirety. Nothing I did in the first half of the game changed anything meaningful about the rest of the game. Then I tried the multiplayer. Although I have to admit that my brief experience was satisfying, that was mostly because of that I found that I was better at it than most playing. That is not a weird thing, considering that all you do in the multiplayer is run around and shoot eachother in microscopic environments. Therefore noone who plays first person shooters regularly is still playing that, which explains my experience. After 20 minutes I was done, I quit and never returned.If you ask me, this game is just boring. I would not recommend that you pay money for it at all to play it.

Posted: March 20, 2014
												[This review only covers single-player campaign.]This entry in the MoH series is EA's blatant attempt to copy Call of Duty. Unfortunately, the game does a lot of things wrong.Things I disliked:- Lack of information. Where are we fighting? Why do we even fight and shoot everyone in sight? Who are the enemies who are simply labeled as "bad guys"? One mission even puts you in a helicopter with machine gun and Hellfire rockets and your objective is to kill all "bad guys" on the ground who desperately try to fight back with AK-74 rifles. - The player is part of an overpowered squad which takes down literally hundreds of "bad guys" while listening to praise from squad mates such as "Nice!", "Good kill!", etc. The result is almost as off-puting as Spec Ops: The Line - however, in case of MoH it is probably unintentional.- The campaign is a bunch of missions glued together with almost no story.- The game is way too easy, even on the highest difficulty; squad mates are immortal and can deal with anything.- A.I. is simply idiotic. Majority of enemies don't use cover and just stand in the open. Many of those who are smarter and decide to go for cover decide to constantly switch between standing, crouching and lying.- Hitboxes don't make sense. 5 bullets in the neck? No problem! 2 bullets in foot? Impossible to survive.- Player's character is unable to climb or do any action unless told to do so.- "Press F to receive ammo" (by asking a squad mate) doesn't work 95 % of the time. However, if it works, the squad mates can provide anything - rifle or machine gun bullets, sniper rounds, rockets ...Things I liked:- The campaign only takes 4-5 hours to beat (on the hardest difficulty).- The gameplay is smooth and feels good; the same with weapons.- Graphics & physics. Mountain ranges provide beautiful vistas and destructible parts of environment make the shootouts interesting.- Contrary to everything mentioned above, 2 missions (out of 10) were well designed and felt pretty great (especially when compared to the rest). Specifically, they were missions 5 (Belly of the Beast) and 9 (Neptune's Net).

Posted: August 21, 2015
												Alright; I think you should know what you are in for with this game. Because despite it marketing itself as a hard as nails, top tier, hardcore shooter - it is nothing more than a CoD-ified matinée blockbuster experience. Explosions a plenty, regenerating health all over the place and more guns than you could shake a stick at.That said; I don't think there is anything wrong with that.I am one of those wierd people who genuinly enjoy the Call of Duty and Battlefield campaigns; I love cheesy war movies and I have spent more than my fair share of time just reading about guns on wikipedia, and for what it is, I, for some reason I really like this game. Like, a lot.Now; let me get this straight - there are a lot of flaws apparent here. Flaws that I, in any other game, would find extremely annoying, such as EXTREME liniarity, lack of an FOV slider and a campaign about as long as your average Lord of The Rings movie. There really isn't anything special about this game and I shouldn't like it, because when I look at it, it just seems to blend in as an average CoD clone. But when I play it; it just feels right.I think it is the settings that the game places you in; the characters all fill their sterotypical roles, but does it well and, just like Call of Duty 3, you learn to feel the comraderie between them. That, mixed with some of the most memorable moments in gaming places this game as a favourite of mine.Performance wise I don't think there will be a problem; it runs well on my rig (i7 4979K 4.0GHz, GTX 980, 16GB RAM), maxed out and I think any modern computer should be able to handle it.I think you have to be a military nut to like this game; because it is essentially just softcore porn for the military interested. And, even though I wouldn't mind paying the 19,99€ that it currently is, I would recommending holding of on a sale as there isn't that much content present here. There is a multiplayer mode (that I loved on the Xbox), but I doubt there is much of a crowd left playing it.

												Alright; I think you should know what you are in for with this game. Because despite it marketing itself as a hard as nails, top tier, hardcore shooter - it is nothing more than a CoD-ified matinée blockbuster experience. Explosions a plenty, regenerating health all over the place and more guns than you could shake a stick at.That said; I don't think there is anything wrong with that.I am one of those wierd people who genuinly enjoy the Call of Duty and Battlefield campaigns; I love cheesy war movies and I have spent more than my fair share of time just reading about guns on wikipedia, and for what it is, I, for some reason I really like this game. Like, a lot.Now; let me get this straight - there are a lot of flaws apparent here. Flaws that I, in any other game, would find extremely annoying, such as EXTREME liniarity, lack of an FOV slider and a campaign about as long as your average Lord of The Rings movie. There really isn't anything special about this game and I shouldn't like it, because when I look at it, it just seems to blend in as an average CoD clone. But when I play it; it just feels right.I think it is the settings that the game places you in; the characters all fill their sterotypical roles, but does it well and, just like Call of Duty 3, you learn to feel the comraderie between them. That, mixed with some of the most memorable moments in gaming places this game as a favourite of mine.Performance wise I don't think there will be a problem; it runs well on my rig (i7 4979K 4.0GHz, GTX 980, 16GB RAM), maxed out and I think any modern computer should be able to handle it.I think you have to be a military nut to like this game; because it is essentially just softcore porn for the military interested. And, even though I wouldn't mind paying the 19,99€ that it currently is, I would recommending holding of on a sale as there isn't that much content present here. There is a multiplayer mode (that I loved on the Xbox), but I doubt there is much of a crowd left playing it.

												The singleplayer is linear, the gunplay is almost a run-and-gun despite having lean mechanics. There are quite a few breaks where the game gives you a minigame where you mark targets for a gunship to fire upon. Gunplay:Walking bloom is not very high and so the run-and-gun playstyle is a possibility. The game also lets you play safer with leaning if you'd prefer that instead. The ammo is infinite if you use the guns you start with on each mission, as you can just ask your teammate for a full set of ammo and you'll get it quickly. Recoil is almost nonexistent and bloom is mostly negligible for most weapons, especially if you can control your firing. Because of this, spraying-and-praying is also a possible play style. If you pick up an enemy weapon, you'll have to get your own ammo from other enemy guns.Difficulty:This game is pretty easy, even on the hardest difficulty. Because of the difficulty and the easy gunplay, I found myself dying simply because I was running and gunning like I was playing DOOM or Shadow Warrior; in other words, I got bored and found myself running far ahead of my team in more open areas to clear a room quickly. You can move and clear so quickly that you may find youself shooting enemies that haven't even settled down to shoot at you yet, or enemies that are still looking at your teammates while you kill him from behind. In short, it's pretty easy if you don't play like an idiot.Graphics:Very meh. Nothing particularly nasty, nothing noteworthy. There are enemy spawn-points in the game where enemeis come out of when you are fighting in the open. Some of these rooms do not render light by intention and are almost completely dark, which is inconsistent.Conclusion:The gunplay is nothing special and quite boring, and the difficulty is too low. Even though I spent less than a dollar on it (through a Humble Bundle) I would personally not buy this game, even on sale. There are some that would be entertained by it, though.5/10, incredibly average.

Posted: March 20, 2014
												[This review only covers single-player campaign.]This entry in the MoH series is EA's blatant attempt to copy Call of Duty. Unfortunately, the game does a lot of things wrong.Things I disliked:- Lack of information. Where are we fighting? Why do we even fight and shoot everyone in sight? Who are the enemies who are simply labeled as "bad guys"? One mission even puts you in a helicopter with machine gun and Hellfire rockets and your objective is to kill all "bad guys" on the ground who desperately try to fight back with AK-74 rifles. - The player is part of an overpowered squad which takes down literally hundreds of "bad guys" while listening to praise from squad mates such as "Nice!", "Good kill!", etc. The result is almost as off-puting as Spec Ops: The Line - however, in case of MoH it is probably unintentional.- The campaign is a bunch of missions glued together with almost no story.- The game is way too easy, even on the highest difficulty; squad mates are immortal and can deal with anything.- A.I. is simply idiotic. Majority of enemies don't use cover and just stand in the open. Many of those who are smarter and decide to go for cover decide to constantly switch between standing, crouching and lying.- Hitboxes don't make sense. 5 bullets in the neck? No problem! 2 bullets in foot? Impossible to survive.- Player's character is unable to climb or do any action unless told to do so.- "Press F to receive ammo" (by asking a squad mate) doesn't work 95 % of the time. However, if it works, the squad mates can provide anything - rifle or machine gun bullets, sniper rounds, rockets ...Things I liked:- The campaign only takes 4-5 hours to beat (on the hardest difficulty).- The gameplay is smooth and feels good; the same with weapons.- Graphics & physics. Mountain ranges provide beautiful vistas and destructible parts of environment make the shootouts interesting.- Contrary to everything mentioned above, 2 missions (out of 10) were well designed and felt pretty great (especially when compared to the rest). Specifically, they were missions 5 (Belly of the Beast) and 9 (Neptune's Net).

												I had almost given up on this game and come to write an incendiary review after the first few missions. So let's get it out of the way: this game is far from perfect.Mouse sensitivity is awkward, it feels fast for small movements and slow for big ones. The AI is pretty weak, as even on hard difficulty, ennemies still seem to think running right in front of you and kneeling before even raising their gun is a good idea (they're not actually surrendering), and they severely suffer from the stormtrooper syndrome (better not shoot the hero). You're the only guy in your squad of elite badass soldiers that really shoots down more than one enemy per encounter. The early missions felt uncompelling and lacking in purpose, with some painfully obvious script checkpoints—that sometimes forget to trigger, forcing you to restart the last sequence. The quad sequences (only one mission) are both eventless and clunky.It gets much better however, and I'm glad I stuck around for it. You get used to the control awkwardness. You live the extraordinary landscape. The ennemies start to feel like they invariably punish you for leaving exposed body parts stick out. Your squad doesn't feel useless anymore. The missions finally get purpose, and I played through the most engaging and memorable FPS sequences I ever played.I can't speak for the multiplayer part that I didn't play.This game is extremely backloaded. It is such a waste that all the bad things about the game appear at the beginning, when it surely drives many players away before they can get to the juicy bits. So if you decide to give this game a chance (and you should), make sure you don't give up on it too easy.Keep in mind, however, that the campaign is very short—I'd wait for a sale if short games make you feel bitter.

												I started playing this game not expecting much.  Then the only reason I continued playing it was just because I could laugh at it. So having finally uninstalled it, here are some of the main things that I find completely ridiculous in this game: Apparently your character's arms are made of wet spaghetti noodles, because while your squadmates have no trouble lifting their arms above their head and hauling themselves onto a ledge, you have to get one of them to boost you up by running over and pressing a button. The game shatters all attempts at being taken seriously when it chooses to call these helping hands "buddy boosts". The plot is dull, the voice acting lifeless (and bad in places), and expects you to care about a bunch of guys whose "names" go from the semi-reasonable (Voodoo) to the hilariously ridiculous (Mother).  Ex: Mother: Okay, we have to go do the thing and then the thing and the stuff.  Voodoo: Thanks, Mom.  Me: YOU ACTUALLY WANT ME TO THINK THIS IS ALL GRITTY AND SERIOUS?!?! The game restricts you at every turn.  There was a point where I tried to enter a house with a wide open door.  I could see inside!  And yet the doorway was just an invisible wall.  Note that this is not always the case, but still...If you can't enter somewhere, just close the door!  On another occasion, I was walking along a cliff and decided to try and jump off - you know, for science.  NOPE.  Invisible wall.  No fence or wall that would be a reasonable blockade - nothing that justified me not being able to do this.  Just the developers saying, "We don't want you to go over there, but we're too lazy to actually show you that." BUDDY BOOSTS. At one point, your character gets blood splattered on his face, and the camera shows blood splats.  Keep in mind that your character is not wearing goggles, thereby implying he has blood on his eyes.  Then your squadmate comes over and magically wipes the blood away!  Thanks for molesting my eyeballs, buddy. The pistol is hilariously overpowered.  I went through entire sections of the game just going crazy with it.  It has enough range that you can snipe people from decently far away, it shoots quite fast, and it has infinite ammo (unlike your other weapons). FREAKING BUDDY BOOSTS. When the game does give you a bit of freedom, it's ridiculous how quickly it can fall apart.  There was a part where I ran ahead of my squad, shot everyone in the area while my team was monologuing, and then ran to the back of the area while the next scene triggered.  After an air strike came through, I pulled out a grenade and counted it off.  After a couple of seconds, I hurled it into a seemingly empty alcove, where a moment later, about five enemy fighters spawned and were immediately blown up. Your squadmates can and often will play the game for you.  There were times were I ran into an area, fired off some shots to get the enemy's attention, and then crouched behind a wall while my squad took out everyone.  Word of advice, devs: Making the player feel completely irrelevant to a game's outcome does not make them want to keep playing. THEY ACTUALLY THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA TO CALL THEM BUDDY BOOSTS WHO THE HELL WAS IN CHARGE OF THAT?!?!?!?!In addition, the plot is dull, the graphics aren't anything special (hooray...gray...), the sound is unremarkable (my friend commented that a hail of gunfire just sounded like hail), and the gameplay is, in many cases, entirely optional.  Just...go play a shooter that actually seems to care about the player.TLDR: THIS GAME SUCKS BECAUSE BUDDY BOOSTS.

As most FPS characters are, the subjects of this game are static characters who neither develop as the game goes on, or are given a chance to really set themselves apart as someone for you to care about. 												As a US Army veteran, it's easy to see the time which was put into this game to make it as accurate as possible (while still keeping it a game). Although the single-player campaign is short, it plays like a movie with you as the main character(s). Aside from giving us a mere glimpse into the skill of our special operations fighting force, it also shows the level of brotherhood these warriors share and the lengths they would go to in order to protect their own. Although there were a few bugs in the game (respawning into an area where you're killed again in seconds with no way to escape, A.I. trying to walk through walls, shoebox-style gameplay where your movement is limited to a pre-defined area, etc.), these are overshadowed by what I consider to be a great story line. If you're looking for a realistic open-world sandbox style FPS, however, you'd have better luck with the ARMA series. I didn't (and won't) bother with the multiplayer, but I can tell you that if you're looking for a great story-driven FPS, look no further than this game. In the end, it will pull at your emotions and give you a glimpse, even if only briefly, into the mind a our great defenders and silent warriors.

Posted: March 11, 2015
												I started playing this game not expecting much.  Then the only reason I continued playing it was just because I could laugh at it.  And then I realized that trying to laugh at it was just making me slowly die inside.  So having finally uninstalled it, here are some of the main things that I find completely ridiculous in this game: Apparently your character's arms are made of wet spaghetti noodles, because while your squadmates have no trouble lifting their arms above their head and hauling themselves onto a ledge, you have to get one of them to boost you up by running over and pressing a button. The game shatters all attempts at being taken seriously when it chooses to call these helping hands "buddy boosts". The plot is dull, the voice acting lifeless (and bad in places), and expects you to care about a bunch of guys whose "names" go from the semi-reasonable (Voodoo) to the hilariously ridiculous (Mother).  Ex: Mother: Okay, we have to go do the thing and then the thing and the stuff.  Voodoo: Thanks, Mom.  Me: YOU ACTUALLY WANT ME TO THINK THIS IS ALL GRITTY AND SERIOUS?!?! The game restricts you at every turn.  There was a point where I tried to enter a house with a wide open door.  I could see inside!  And yet the doorway was just an invisible wall.  Note that this is not always the case, but still...If you can't enter somewhere, just close the door!  On another occasion, I was walking along a cliff and decided to try and jump off - you know, for science.  NOPE.  Invisible wall.  No fence or wall that would be a reasonable blockade - nothing that justified me not being able to do this.  Just the developers saying, "We don't want you to go over there, but we're too lazy to actually show you that." BUDDY BOOSTS. At one point, your character gets blood splattered on his face, and the camera shows blood splats.  Keep in mind that your character is not wearing goggles, thereby implying he has blood on his eyes.  Then your squadmate comes over and magically wipes the blood away!  Thanks for molesting my eyeballs, buddy. The pistol is hilariously overpowered.  I went through entire sections of the game just going crazy with it.  It has enough range that you can snipe people from decently far away, it shoots quite fast, and it has infinite ammo (unlike your other weapons). FREAKING BUDDY BOOSTS. When the game does give you a bit of freedom, it's ridiculous how quickly it can fall apart.  There was a part where I ran ahead of my squad, shot everyone in the area while my team was monologuing, and then ran to the back of the area while the next scene triggered.  After an air strike came through, I pulled out a grenade and counted it off.  After a couple of seconds, I hurled it into a seemingly empty alcove, where a moment later, about five enemy fighters spawned and were immediately blown up. Your squadmates can and often will play the game for you.  There were times were I ran into an area, fired off some shots to get the enemy's attention, and then crouched behind a wall while my squad took out everyone.  Word of advice, devs: Making the player feel completely irrelevant to a game's outcome does not make them want to keep playing. THEY ACTUALLY THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA TO CALL THEM BUDDY BOOSTS WHO THE HELL WAS IN CHARGE OF THAT?!?!?!?!In addition, the plot is dull, the graphics aren't anything special (hooray...gray...), the sound is unremarkable (my friend commented that a hail of gunfire just sounded like hail), and the gameplay is, in many cases, entirely optional.  Just...go play a shooter that actually seems to care about the player.TLDR: THIS GAME SUCKS BECAUSE BUDDY BOOSTS.

												I will never understand the kicking that this game got in the reviews on Steam. Yes, it's linear but that's because it's telling a story in the midst of a war - an open world option was never going to work, at least not with the story the devs wanted to tell. I love non-linear gaming (hell look at the time I've spent in GTA's Liberty City, Sleeping Dogs' Hong Kong etc) but it's not always the best solution.The story is actually very good given the quality of others in this genre, and by the time you're down to a sidearm, no cover, and every other Ranger is out of ammo... well, no spoilers but you do end up reacting out loud as if you were really there. Oh and if you're not on the bleeding edge of hardware, the Unreal 3 engine here gives you an easy ride.Don't think of it as a combat sim, think of it as a story you're being allowed to play through.

So having finally uninstalled it, here are some of the main things that I find completely ridiculous in this game: Apparently your character's arms are made of wet spaghetti noodles, because while your squadmates have no trouble lifting their arms above their head and hauling themselves onto a ledge, you have to get one of them to boost you up by running over and pressing a button. The game shatters all attempts at being taken seriously when it chooses to call these helping hands "buddy boosts". The plot is dull, the voice acting lifeless (and bad in places), and expects you to care about a bunch of guys whose "names" go from the semi-reasonable (Voodoo) to the hilariously ridiculous (Mother).  Ex: Mother: Okay, we have to go do the thing and then the thing and the stuff.  Voodoo: Thanks, Mom.  Me: YOU ACTUALLY WANT ME TO THINK THIS IS ALL GRITTY AND SERIOUS?!?! The game restricts you at every turn.  There was a point where I tried to enter a house with a wide open door.  I could see inside!  And yet the doorway was just an invisible wall.  Note that this is not always the case, but still...If you can't enter somewhere, just close the door!  On another occasion, I was walking along a cliff and decided to try and jump off - you know, for science.  NOPE.  Invisible wall.  No fence or wall that would be a reasonable blockade - nothing that justified me not being able to do this.  Just the developers saying, "We don't want you to go over there, but we're too lazy to actually show you that." BUDDY BOOSTS. At one point, your character gets blood splattered on his face, and the camera shows blood splats.  Keep in mind that your character is not wearing goggles, thereby implying he has blood on his eyes.  Then your squadmate comes over and magically wipes the blood away!  Thanks for molesting my eyeballs, buddy. The pistol is hilariously overpowered.  I went through entire sections of the game just going crazy with it.  It has enough range that you can snipe people from decently far away, it shoots quite fast, and it has infinite ammo (unlike your other weapons). FREAKING BUDDY BOOSTS. When the game does give you a bit of freedom, it's ridiculous how quickly it can fall apart.  There was a part where I ran ahead of my squad, shot everyone in the area while my team was monologuing, and then ran to the back of the area while the next scene triggered.  After an air strike came through, I pulled out a grenade and counted it off.  After a couple of seconds, I hurled it into a seemingly empty alcove, where a moment later, about five enemy fighters spawned and were immediately blown up. Your squadmates can and often will play the game for you.  There were times were I ran into an area, fired off some shots to get the enemy's attention, and then crouched behind a wall while my squad took out everyone.  Word of advice, devs: Making the player feel completely irrelevant to a game's outcome does not make them want to keep playing. THEY ACTUALLY THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA TO CALL THEM BUDDY BOOSTS WHO THE HELL WAS IN CHARGE OF THAT?!?!?!?!In addition, the plot is dull, the graphics aren't anything special (hooray...gray...), the sound is unremarkable (my friend commented that a hail of gunfire just sounded like hail), and the gameplay is, in many cases, entirely optional.  Just...go play a shooter that actually seems to care about the player.TLDR: THIS GAME SUCKS BECAUSE BUDDY BOOSTS.

Posted: August 21, 2014
Recommendation level:|-|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|▓▓▓▓▓▓|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|+|Medal of Honor can be compared mostly to the recent episodes of the Call of Duty franchise. You get a military shooter with very linear and short campaign and a multiplayer mode which was designed for the masses. In both parts MoH fails to compete against the successful series. However, there are some parts which are more valuable than in the case of the other. I played through the game twice, so it can be considered as one of my favorite military shooters to date.I would start with the graphics and overall design. Unlike Warfighter, MoH uses the Unreal Engine which is a good choice for any shooters. The utilization however is not the best. The game has the usual "previous generation console issues" like blurry textures, worthless anti-aliasing and optimization problems. Also I need to mention that the level design is pretty varied. The night scenes mostly look good with all the lightning, but sometimes I encounter areas which are so poorly detailed. There are almost completely empty rooms, small flames coming from nowhere and a other annoying things. It is maybe not fair to judge a game's graphics four years after release, but I was not amazed at the time when it came out. In 2010 I have seen much better visuals already and the cut-scenes in the game are so disappointing, they are just ruining the atmosphere.One of the better parts of the game is the gameplay. The gunplay is fun, however the behaviour of the weapons sometimes clumsy and weird. Overall it is still acceptable. There are multiple weapons to use from both sides during missions. The short campaign includes the usual sections, like sneaking, sniping, shooting with mg, etc. There are some good ideas either, which seems pretty experimental and brave at times. Some of the areas are nicely done, allowing some freedom and variation, though most of them are pretty linear and strict. At one point on day 2 we crossed under a bridge while troops were marching above us. The game gave me the control, but I was told to let them pass. Once I tried to shoot the separated soldier, all the others started to shoot. Actually, after a few shots they fled, and my partner just desperately wanted to climb the bank of the river bed and chase them. So, sometimes you got more freedom, but in these cases you would never know what happens if you do not stick to the plan, you can even fail the mission because of a bug. And, if I speak about bugs, I encountered a few during my gameplay. Sometimes these breaks the game, like when one of your teammate stuck into a wall, so you need to reload a previous checkpoint. Fortunately, the game saves pretty often, so you do not lose much progress if something bad happens. These linear sequences sometimes nicely choreographed, so I do not complain about it all the time.I have mixed opinions about the writing and storytelling too. You have to control various soldiers during the campaign. These are from different classes, allowing you to explore the full arsenal of the division. However, this may prevent the connection to one certain soldier, making characters less memorable. As I mentioned before, the cutscenes are not managed to give me a good impression, but some of them are exceptions. I really liked the ending. The tense was pretty high in those last minutes, which elevated the game quite a bit. It was really sad and touching. The whole storytelling tries a different approach to the genre and sometimes it is what moves the player forward. I recently watched the Lone Survivor movie and I had similar feeling during the playtime. The game gives back the feel of the war zone in the middle east well.Now comes my favourite part of the game, the audio part. Ramin Djawadi wrote an amazing soundtrack for this title, which earns the game a playthrough on its own. I played the game with lowered effects volume, so that the music can be more enjoyable. The album is also one of my favourite military soundtrack album. The sounds are also pretty much in place. You do not hear anything awkward. The weapon sounds are good, the impacts makes you feel the pressure during combat. The overall feedback is great. Last part in the audio section is the dialogues. This is a shooter, so the most frequent lines you will hear are orders for movement, shoot and others. The lines during cut-scenes and between fights are mostly passable. They do not worsen the experience.Overall, this game feels like an early release. It would needed more polish and work on details. I do not say, that multiplayer could compete against any of the CoD's, but the singleplayer part could be much more enjoyable. That way this could be a must have. However, I still recommend this game, because it is still closer to my heart than many other shooters out there.MY OPINION: 7.5/10 (GOOD)Graphics: 7/10World Design: 7/10Gameplay: 8/10Sound: 9/10Replay Value: 6/10PS: I did not play the multiplayer as it was not populated too much even at the time of my first playthrough.

												Single Player Review: Is this game good? That depends on what you are looking for and how you define it. Its about Afghanistan and thats a touchy subject.I don't think that Danger Close was trying to make light of the war in Afghanistan. I also think a distinction needs to be made between a war game/movie, and an action game/movie. War movies should not be fun, they should be dramatic, even painful, as to respect the gravity of the situation/people invoved. Whereas action movies/games can be fun, because they generally focus around a caricatured protagonist who is the embodiment of some particular virtue. This distinction would be what separates Medal of Honor from Call of Duty Modern Warfare 1-3.If this game is a war game then yes. If this game is an action game then no. But that distinction can really only be made in the mind of the player.

Posted: December 1, 2013
												The game seems to be trying to show the realism of war, the bleakness- as the colour palette shows. But the game mechanics prevent it from doing this. Lack of health packs means lack of tension, ammo can be gotten from team mates so the fact that you have limited ammo in your weapons is a bit of an illusion. At many points during the game the music will just stop. One example is during a mission as a character you’ve never played before, you and your three (every level is you and 3 invulnerable team-mates) holding off against waves of insurgents. There’s no music to provide realism and tension! Except there is no tension, the enemies come at you from the same paths again and again, I’ve been playing this character for about 20 minutes, why should I care if he lives or dies. MAKE ME CARE GAME. If the game is relying on the fact that it’s based on real-life events to make me care about the characters then it’s sorely mistaken. The game’s mechanics of what is essentially unlimited ammo, team-mates that absorb whole clips of both enemy and friendly fire, incredibly stupid AI, bullet spongy enemies, extreme linearity and oh much more mean that it cannot in all fairness successfully convey real-life situations and make me feel the horrors of war. Either you go the ARMA route where one bullet can kill you, where the realism of warfare is far more apparent than MoH or you go the CoD route of arcade mayhem while conveying emotions through storytelling. Medal of honour is an absolute mess. The game is disjointed, horribly disjointed. The story is only carried by the cinematics which bookend levels, if your players need the cinematics to follow the story/care about what is going on then you’ve failed at FPS storytelling. Every few levels you change character, moving from special forces to simply infantry. That’s fine in and of itself, but I actually became slightly disorientated, if you skip the cinematic it can take a few minutes to work out who you are playing as based on your location and team members. Not that you can give any orders to your team mates, even medal of honour European assault let you do that. They just follow scripted events and bark orders at you. The game has predictable scripted sequences that even Activision would laugh at. You see all the Call of duty references? That’s because it’s so ♥♥♥♥ing clear that MoH is EA’ response to call of duty. Now in 2013 it’s obvious that they’ve focused on Battlefield as their counter to CoD, even though the games are very different (multiplayer wise) single player wise they’re both a boring as one another.  But of course, it’s the multiplayer component that sells both games.Medal of Honor lacks colour, which is part of this aim at ‘realism’- though in the sense of feeling not in gameplay. Its so boring and depressing, which sums up MoH. Not depressing because of its focus on real-life events or questioning the legality and morality of what the soldiers are actually fighting for (which would actually make an interesting twist to modern military shooters) but because it shows complete and utter disregard for originality and the medal of honour franchise. The lack of a HUD reiterates part of this  ‘realistic approach’, yet in a game where you cans till take a handful of bullets before dying it seems like a bit of useless attempt at getting across whatever message about war Danger close are trying to convey.Forget about the series being set in ww2, even if MoH were set in the second world war, itd still be ♥♥♥♥ing boring. The guns feel boring, and the enemies are not interesting in the slightest. They’re just Nazis in middle-eastern garb. By that I mean they have no character outside of them being EVIL. We don’t see anything that makes us question why we are killing hundreds of these guys, it’s like the game just paints the word TERRORIST in great big letters on their heads. That’s all the motivation we need apparently. Maybe that’s a joke at how soldiers have to remove those thoughts from their heads in order to do their job properly. Or it’s just lazy storytelling, you pick. Graphically this game looks about 3 years older than it should. 2011 was only a year away which would herald the use of the frostbite 2 engine. Even battlefield bad company 2 looked far superior to Medal of honour and that came out the same bloody year. The only decent textures are on people’s faces, everything else oozes muddy brown pixels. I’d argue that this is due to an attempt at making a console beating CoD killer, but EA must have been utterly delusional to think that. If CoD gets complaints for being stale then MoH is a loaf of bread left behind two biscuit tins for 4 years, dusted off and then put in shiny packaging to sell to people who only want call of duty clones. Not that it can even be called a clone; the changes it does make (aside from the MoH ability to lean around cover) make the game into a boring mess. Oh and the bugs, these mainly revolve around the AI and the ragdoll/physics effects, at least they make me laugh I guess, something in this game has to. The studio behind this game have an interesting history, as EA Los Angeles they created the battle for middle earth games, all MoH games from Frontline and created both red alert 3 and the terrible ending to Command & Conquer, tiberian twilight. A history of some great and some terrible games. Rebranded as ‘Danger Close’ the studio made the two modern Medal of Honour games, the last of which has been classed as a franchise killer. Now EA have rebranded the studio yet again as DICE Los Angeles, and set them to work on the extremely anticipated game, Battlefront 3. I really hope danger close rethink their fps game design. Clearly modern military shooters were not a genre the studio was good at, taking tons of tropes and clichés, covering it in cardboard and serving it on a grey plate in a grey room for grey people to sit and eat while they laugh at re-runs of Miranda. That all said, Battlefront 3 is being designed by the DICE team behind Battlefield, so hopefully Danger Close, I mean DICE LA, won’t be able to suck the life out of this one.

												      I bought this game with one reason, that I loved the old Medal of Honor games, my personal favorite being Rising Sun. For the longest time I wondered what happened to the series and why it fell off the face of the Eart. Well the history of it is old game developers who worked for EA in the Medal of Honor division left to creat their own FPS war game, it was called Call of Duty. At first Call of Duty could never live up to the greatest FPS game Medal of Honor was. But then with the release of Call of Duty Modern Warfare, which was a came that captivated the audience at the time. In a rush EA's Medal of Honor divison started to panic and released a game in hopes to beat Modern Warfare, the end result was a game that was rushed.       Medal of Honor came out with this game, a game that takes place in other people's prespective of the modern war, but the end result of the game was left in the dust and left for old Medal of Honor fans. But that raises the question... How is this game?      In truth the game isn't remarkable and certainly doesn't touch the previous Medal of Honor games. The controls in the game are nice, similar to that of COD, the story is hardly compelling, the writing is decent, the gameplay was excellent and possibly one of the saddest NPC's deaths ever.        For the cons of the game it's graphics are poor, the writing is the not the best, A.I can be derpy at times and you can have the "who the f*ck is shooting me" syndrome. But as for a game, it's actually a lot of fun. I'll tell you what it is a lot better than the following; COD Ghosts, COD Advanced Warfare, COD Infinate Warfare, Mass Effect Andromeda and No Man's Sky.       Final word: If you were a fan of the old Medal of Honor series and want to recap some of that old feelings when you played the old ones, you're not finding it here. But it is a fun game to play, but for those of you who don't what Medal of Honor is, go play the older games and then consider buying this one.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												Single Player Review: Is this game good? That depends on what you are looking for and how you define it. Its about Afghanistan and thats a touchy subject.I don't think that Danger Close was trying to make light of the war in Afghanistan. I also think a distinction needs to be made between a war game/movie, and an action game/movie. War movies should not be fun, they should be dramatic, even painful, as to respect the gravity of the situation/people invoved. Whereas action movies/games can be fun, because they generally focus around a caricatured protagonist who is the embodiment of some particular virtue. This distinction would be what separates Medal of Honor from Call of Duty Modern Warfare 1-3.If this game is a war game then yes. If this game is an action game then no. But that distinction can really only be made in the mind of the player.

And then I realized that trying to laugh at it was just making me slowly die inside.  So having finally uninstalled it, here are some of the main things that I find completely ridiculous in this game: Apparently your character's arms are made of wet spaghetti noodles, because while your squadmates have no trouble lifting their arms above their head and hauling themselves onto a ledge, you have to get one of them to boost you up by running over and pressing a button. The game shatters all attempts at being taken seriously when it chooses to call these helping hands "buddy boosts". The plot is dull, the voice acting lifeless (and bad in places), and expects you to care about a bunch of guys whose "names" go from the semi-reasonable (Voodoo) to the hilariously ridiculous (Mother).  Ex: Mother: Okay, we have to go do the thing and then the thing and the stuff.  Voodoo: Thanks, Mom.  Me: YOU ACTUALLY WANT ME TO THINK THIS IS ALL GRITTY AND SERIOUS?!?! The game restricts you at every turn.  There was a point where I tried to enter a house with a wide open door.  I could see inside!  And yet the doorway was just an invisible wall.  Note that this is not always the case, but still...If you can't enter somewhere, just close the door!  On another occasion, I was walking along a cliff and decided to try and jump off - you know, for science.  NOPE.  Invisible wall.  No fence or wall that would be a reasonable blockade - nothing that justified me not being able to do this.  Just the developers saying, "We don't want you to go over there, but we're too lazy to actually show you that." BUDDY BOOSTS. At one point, your character gets blood splattered on his face, and the camera shows blood splats.  Keep in mind that your character is not wearing goggles, thereby implying he has blood on his eyes.  Then your squadmate comes over and magically wipes the blood away!  Thanks for molesting my eyeballs, buddy. The pistol is hilariously overpowered.  I went through entire sections of the game just going crazy with it.  It has enough range that you can snipe people from decently far away, it shoots quite fast, and it has infinite ammo (unlike your other weapons). FREAKING BUDDY BOOSTS. When the game does give you a bit of freedom, it's ridiculous how quickly it can fall apart.  There was a part where I ran ahead of my squad, shot everyone in the area while my team was monologuing, and then ran to the back of the area while the next scene triggered.  After an air strike came through, I pulled out a grenade and counted it off.  After a couple of seconds, I hurled it into a seemingly empty alcove, where a moment later, about five enemy fighters spawned and were immediately blown up. Your squadmates can and often will play the game for you.  There were times were I ran into an area, fired off some shots to get the enemy's attention, and then crouched behind a wall while my squad took out everyone.  Word of advice, devs: Making the player feel completely irrelevant to a game's outcome does not make them want to keep playing. THEY ACTUALLY THOUGHT IT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA TO CALL THEM BUDDY BOOSTS WHO THE HELL WAS IN CHARGE OF THAT?!?!?!?!In addition, the plot is dull, the graphics aren't anything special (hooray...gray...), the sound is unremarkable (my friend commented that a hail of gunfire just sounded like hail), and the gameplay is, in many cases, entirely optional.  Just...go play a shooter that actually seems to care about the player.TLDR: THIS GAME SUCKS BECAUSE BUDDY BOOSTS.

Posted: August 21, 2015
												Alright; I think you should know what you are in for with this game. Because despite it marketing itself as a hard as nails, top tier, hardcore shooter - it is nothing more than a CoD-ified matinée blockbuster experience. Explosions a plenty, regenerating health all over the place and more guns than you could shake a stick at.That said; I don't think there is anything wrong with that.I am one of those wierd people who genuinly enjoy the Call of Duty and Battlefield campaigns; I love cheesy war movies and I have spent more than my fair share of time just reading about guns on wikipedia, and for what it is, I, for some reason I really like this game. Like, a lot.Now; let me get this straight - there are a lot of flaws apparent here. Flaws that I, in any other game, would find extremely annoying, such as EXTREME liniarity, lack of an FOV slider and a campaign about as long as your average Lord of The Rings movie. There really isn't anything special about this game and I shouldn't like it, because when I look at it, it just seems to blend in as an average CoD clone. But when I play it; it just feels right.I think it is the settings that the game places you in; the characters all fill their sterotypical roles, but does it well and, just like Call of Duty 3, you learn to feel the comraderie between them. That, mixed with some of the most memorable moments in gaming places this game as a favourite of mine.Performance wise I don't think there will be a problem; it runs well on my rig (i7 4979K 4.0GHz, GTX 980, 16GB RAM), maxed out and I think any modern computer should be able to handle it.I think you have to be a military nut to like this game; because it is essentially just softcore porn for the military interested. And, even though I wouldn't mind paying the 19,99€ that it currently is, I would recommending holding of on a sale as there isn't that much content present here. There is a multiplayer mode (that I loved on the Xbox), but I doubt there is much of a crowd left playing it.
